Home Dec 25, 1854
Dear Sister Anna,
I have but little time to write this evening, and moreover I believe I am not in debt to you, - but think I must write a little letter "nevertheless" - A letter from Isaac came last Saturday - He writes that he hopes to get away immediately after the 26th - and will return by way of Elyria- Says he may be obliged to stop some days in Chicago - and in New York City also, it may be - I do hope not long, for you can imagine I suppose that I am impatient to see him - These last weeks do seem so long - But have I not every thing to make me glad and thankful? If he only comes at last, safe and well, and finds us in health, what more can I ask? Isaac said Charles was coming by way of 
Written along the left side:
I am just finishing a little thibet dress for Mayo - Dark red

He wears drawers - short dresses & common print aprons with long sleeves - He is outdoors about

every day -
Completed

your house too - I suppose you have seen him long before this, and that he is now in Milo. What a happy family they must be - Albina will think her troubles are all ended. I have good news from Bangor quite frequently - I should like to step in and sit with mother and Lucy some of these afternoons - Isn't it good that dear little Percie is so well. I am longing to see him and the little "G.E.M" - I like the name now better than the first. Do not you? Mallie must enjoy the winter much with both her sisters. I am glad they can be with her - She is a dear Mallie I think.
How are Hattie & Libbie this winter and what are they doing? A great deal of love to them - I wonder if you have had any cold weather this winter? We have, and snow besides - It is piled up splendidly all about us, and I do delight to see it - The drifts are in
Completed

every imaginable shape - steeples & towers and palaces - now a smooth surface, and now like the waves of ocean - I do love to look at them - I have seen the same hundreds of times before, but it all seems new, this winter, and more than ever beautiful - perhaps because I've been two winters where the snow is minimal, and they have mud instead.
Mayo has attained much since you saw him - He is usually very well & running about every where - He is hardy still from morning till night - has one little nap - seldom more than one hour and oftener less.
Isaac writes that you have been enjoying a visit from the son living in Peru with his family - You must have been quite busy I think - I hope you are all well - I shall hear all about you by Isaac, when he comes. Is "Lottie" well? I should love to be better acquainted with her - I enclose
Completed

with this a letter for Isaac - I presume it will reach Elyria in season for him -
I haste, but with much love to you all,
Sister Nettie
[upside down] Mrs. E. De Witt
Completed

April 54
Du Quoin, Apr. 10, 1854
My dear Mother,
This is the first time I have made an attempt to use a pen since this last attack of illness, and my hand goes zigzag - I can hardly control it at all. I am very much better than I was a week since but my strength is weakness yet. I gain however every day I think. This is Sunday morning - Charles was here as usual to spend Sabbath and Samuel also - It is a real comfort to have Charles here - to have him come into our room and talk about you all. He has gone this morning back to his work. This is a cold blustering morning. It is cold at least compared with the bright, warm, sunny days of last week. Every day was fine. Isaac was at home all the week and we went to ride every day. The wild flowers are beginning to bloom in the woods; the grass and spring wheat are beautifully green, peach and apple trees are in blossom - pear trees & cherry also - Everything about us looks like a new made world - O I do enjoy the Spring - Each as it comes, seems to me the most delightful of all. I suppose
Completed

[top of page was torn]
with you.
getting...and they seem to trouble him considerable, so that it is harder to take care of him just now. Two teeth are through. He creeps all over the floor, very fast indeed love to scrabble for the door when it is open and sit - close to it and look out at the cows and the chicken, - jabbering and crowing to them the while in baby way. He is delighted if he can get to my work basket and tip it over, thinks it is the finest plaything he can get hold of. He loves dearly to be in the floor and it is so warm now that I do not ear to have him on it. He had on the little warm soft stockings you sent him this morning. We are wanting to see the little ones at Milo. Charlie must be quite an important member of the family. Going to be a Rail Road man is he? Well, perhaps he may be. He seems to be quite a business character.  _ I have been reading Gallaudets Scripture Biography. Moses, David etc. They are very full of interest, and make me love, more than Ever, the historical part of the Bible. Moses is one of the most interesting characters of the series. I never thought before how much there was to admire and wonder at in his character
Completed

Dearest page torn
Most Affectionately Isaac
{Evening}

Isaac has been in the office all day long with some dozen men settling accounts and paying away monies and he is completely weeried out and says he has no brains left so I do not see but he must be excused from writing. I shall feel sadly to have him out here alone. I am so fearful lest he should exert himself too much in the warm days and become sick, but I hope he will be careful - he says he mean to be so. Mr. Roots of Mt. Hawkins, where Isaac first boarded has been in to day - came to bring Isaac the month's stock of money. He sat in our room some time. Says I must be sure to get very well indeed before I go back East and not carry any Evil report of a good country. His family are quite healthy here Bindie Mayo has gone to sleep. He usually sleep finely all night and sometimes till quite late in the morning, bu he does not sleep much in the day. I am trying to sew some again now, but I dare not attempt much lest I make myself sick again. It is hard to get any help about sewing here - indeed it is next to impossible. I shall only do what
Completed

must be done page torn, words missing till I am home. Isaac is one of the page torn, words missing in the whole world. I know he is about as good a doctor as anybody. I believe he has done more than all the doctor could do to make me well, and we have quite a good physician too.

 Mr. Keyes is preparing the mail - it goes very early in the morning, and I must not keep him waiting. love to all, from
                                                                                                                                                                  Nettie

[right-hand side]  Nettie     DuQuoin

                             April 1854
Completed

1856
                                                                                                    Thursday noon
                                                                                                         Aug, 2d --

Dear mother

                  Isaac is writing to Samuel so I will put in a note. We feel now since Samuel's last letter came, very anxious to hear again both from dear Lucy and the precious baby. Do you not begin to be tired & worn out - dear mother - not so much with care as with anxious watching? I do hope your health will not fail, and that the babe and its mother will gain rapidly, or slowly, - I suppose it cannot be expected they will improve very fast. We think of you all many times in the day. A letter, good & kind, came from Mallie by last mail, from Searsport. It is hard for her to be away from Lucy so long. O how I do long to see you all. It is a comfort to hear so often. Samuel is very kind about writing,
Completed

You would love to see the babies now. They are full enough of mischief and fun. Willie is sly - never laughs without a reason. Wilder is full of glee at nobody knows what. Mayo says "I want to go to Bangor to Percie's house. I want to see Percie and Aunt Lucy." He says Lucy quite plainly now. Such a rainy day as we are having - rainy all day yesterday too, and all the night before that - a long chilly rain. I am making new pants for Mayo out of Isaac's old ones, and making a pair of dresses for babies also ad some nightdresses. Those we made at Milo have lasted until now - they begin to be tight. What wee things you must need for the little Alice. I should love to see her. I do hope she will be spared for her mother's sake at least.

                                                                                              In haste your loving
                                                                                                          Nettie
Completed

A.P.M. Mother.

Nettie P.M.
to Anna N.M.
Oct 9 1856
Dunbarton, Oct 9 - 1856
My dear Mother
It seems strange to write Oct., for it hot as a day in July. Isaac has gone to Concord and Jenny with him - They had shopping to do & then the State Fair is holden there just now. So it is a busy day for us who are at home -, Asenath can do nothing when baby is awake but care for him unless she does it with him in her arms - He is getting his upper teeth and his bowels are considerably disturbed & he is so fretful that it takes about all one person's time to take care of him The doctor says a change of air would
Completed

benefit him more than any thing else so on his account we feel anxious to get away - But it will be a trial to go leaving mother so feeble - Father is gaining fast now and will doubtless soon regain accustomed health - But I feel very anxious about mother - Now and then a day I feel encouraged and the next disheartened again. The dysentery with her, has become chronic or perhaps changed to diarrhea - As for myself I gain very slowly - I had not much strength to boast of before I was sick, and now my limbs will hardly support me about the house - The least exercise beyond my strength gives me diarrhea - But I think I do gain a little, and hope soon gain faster.
Completed

O! how I would love to see you and talk with you! Your letters have done us so much good - I know that you are lonely indeed, and you can feel what a blank is in our hearts - So strange and empty - the whole house looks - dear little Wilder - alone. You know how we miss them - more & more each day. I do rejoice in the midst of sorrowing when I think that dear Isaac is with me still - yes, I would lose all the dear children, much as I love them, easier, far easier than I could part with him. O how thankful I was that he escaped with so light an attack of the disease and that I was not so sick as the others so that it was not so hard to take care of me - I think a journey would benefit us all - so the Dr.
Completed

tells us, and we shall try it as soon as he thinks it will do for me to ride-
I should dearly love to be with you at Bangor this minute, & had not our arrangements been made beforehand so that it was difficult to change, I think we should have gone there.
Kiss dear little P.P. & all the children for me - I shall write to Albina as soon as I can - I am glad the clothes fit - The old pair of pants I thought he could wear up at Milo some, & then they would do to mind the other pair with. Dear little Mayo never wore the little plaid ones - They were finished just as he was taken sick - We thank you for the beautiful poetry you sent us. Pray dear mother that we may so spend our days on Earth that we may go to our precious ones though they can never come to us - Much love to all from 
Your ever loving Nettie
Completed

Nettie P. Metcalf
to Anna M Metcalf
Nov 1858
Elyria, Ohio

                                                                                                                                                         Saturday Eve. Nov. 13, 1858

My dear mother,-
It seems a long time since I have myself written to you - indeed I have not written many letters of late to any one. but I have thought of you and loved you all the while. I am all alone with the children this evening. Isaac is down town, the girls are out and Rollin down to his uncle's to see his sick mother. Wilder is sleeping nicely, but Charly wakes every few moments - he has taken some cold, and finds it hard to breathe easily. It does seem strange to see our baby Charly trudging about the house on his own feet - We have
Completed

hardly become accustomed to it yet, though he seems quite at home himself - Wilder delights to lead him about - makes him go too fast and fall sometimes. We went to Cleveland last week - bought Wilder a regular little over coat; drab, trimmed with drab velvet - got him too, a box of lettered blocks, which seemed to take his mind more than the coat. He tried the coat on, walked about a little and then said, "Well now, let's take it off, and lay it away in the drawer." He has not sucked his thumb since these things came. He says, "I used to suck my thumb, when I was a little boy; but I'm a big boy now, and don't suck it a bit." He wanted to know the other day if Jesus Christ went
Completed

right straight up into heaven, when he went away from the Earth, and if the the  cover was up, so that he did'nt  bump his head. He is very full of questions Anna & I have some new furs. She will tell you about them, I suppose - bought at Cleveland for $52.50 - Tippet & cuffs never sold before for less than $65,00. We did not get muffs - They would have been $10,00 extra - I am dreading to wear mine - If I had my old ones, I was saying to Isaac, I should have worn them several times before now, & the prospect is for a very cold day tomorrow - It is very cold this evening - Isaac has come He says the Dr told Anna if she did not wear her furs tomorrow, she should not go to
Completed

meeting with him. We talk of having a sewing machine together, Anna and I - I have been very busy indeed sewing - Charly wore out two or three dresses entirely while creeping - I have finished two blue ones for him A blue, out of the two blue ones he wore last winter and the crimson & black that was Libby's - Like Percy's waist. And have two more thicker ones partly made. Wilder wears sacks & pants - Has three every day sack aprons - one handsome plaid sack - These, with their under clothing, and various mending & making for the rest of us have kept me employed - I am making one sack and cape for Charly now - outside garment. It is a crimson & black, plaid of camel
Completed

I only want to tell you one or two of Wilder's sayings - A few nights ago he did not feel very well, and was told he could ask God to make him better Next morning he was about as well as ever - He was asked if he had thanked God for making him well. He looked up with a very pleased face and said "There He did, did'nt He."
Night before last - he was walking on the verandah with me, while I wheeled baby to sleep in the carriage - Isaac & Jenny both gone to meeting. He took his thumb out of his mouth, and pointed up, and said "that is the sky, way up there - Are God & good people up there"? Pretty soon he said, "I should'nt dare to die - said it two or three
Completed

times before I understood him - I asked him why - He said "because I could not walk there, and I should'nt be here - I should be way off - I do'nt know what made him talk so, unless he was remembering what was told him when the little Rood children died - that they were dead and buried up in the ground and could'nt see their father and mother here any more. He begins to ask many questions.
Jenny is going to leave us in the course of a month - She is studying arithmetic at home now.
A great amount of love to Almeda, Lissie & James - I should so love to have them near us - Perhaps it may be so - Charley calls-
Lovingly, Nettie
Charly can say Papa & Mama-
Completed

Try to help Father, and Eliza too, as much as you can.
Loving Mother
[upside down] Charlie
Completed

Dear Charlie -
I thank you and Wilder greatly for your letters - I meant to write to you, this time, but I must let it go till next time, for the letter must go to the office - Will you kiss Anna & John for me? I think you & Wilder will be the very best of boys now mother is gone - Do you get your clothes torn much?
Completed

Dunbarton, Jan. 19, 1850.
Will my friend please accept my thanks for the beautiful and valuable book just presented? I had never seen it before. It will certainly afford much pleasure and instruction in connection with the perusal of Shakspeare - I do not progress very rapidly in reading Shakspeare  as my time for reading is quite limited at present. I have been absent from home so much, that now, parents, brothers and sister claim considerable of my time. And besides, I am reading each play twice, and now shall add to this Mrs. Jamison's "Characteristics." - The art of discerning between the good and bad, in the books we read, is of great importance; is it not sometimes a very difficult thing - So often does error appear in the garb of truth, and so much buried truth is there, amidst the rubbish of error.
The feelings expressed in your letter are reciprocated. If visiting me, or writing to me, can increase, in any degree your enjoyment, I should be happy to have you do so. I do not expect to find friends
Completed

perfect in mind or manners, and often wonder when considering my own defects, why kind Heaven has granted me so many and so worthy ones. But it is my part to be grateful for them, and endeavor always to merit their esteem, and profit by their superiority. Your manners and conversation, if now, as you have expressed it, but half formed, promise much for the future, - But what are they to this "warm, true heart within"? Far more delightful is it, to "find" and "stir its depths" than to admire pleasing manners, or imposing address. I know full well in my own experience, what it is to feel much more than shrinking nature will permit me to express, by word or act. Can we not, in this respect, make mutual allowance? And in this I do most certainly feel that your charity and forbearance will be far the most severely tasked. Should you know me better, as I am willing should be the case if you desire it to be so, I am sure you will discover much, I fear more than you think, to be corrected and forgiven.
Shall be happy to hear from you, and to see you, whenever convenient.
Antoinette -
Completed

Dunbarton, March 14, 1850 -
My dear friend,
I welcomed your letter this afternoon, in the midst of whitewashing and papering, and of course, left everything and ran away to read it. - I think you were very kind to write so speedily - I was hoping to hear from you to day, but tried not to expect too strongly, lest, with your many duties, you should be obliged to delay. I am very glad you succeeded in performing your part of the service at Newport, so pleasantly to yourself and so satisfactorily to all. Mr. Chase is much favored in having an aid in whom he can so safely confide. The Report you sent came to day. I certainly hope the Road will be completed, and that you will remain in New Hampshire, so that we may often have the pleasure of your society.
Probably you are now enjoying much, in the society of treasured friends - mother, sisters, brothers and perhaps others. Hope you find your brother 
written up the left side:
as I would have it. But it seemed as great an act - so mighty in its consequences - they might reach through time and through eternity - But I have asked for aid and for direction and I doubt not you have done so. And when I think of this, I can but feel sure that all will be well - A letter, or your presence would be very welcome. Quite a long letter this. I usually write more than I think I shall when I commence
Truly -
Your Antoinette
Completed

improving in health. Mother thinks she knows somewhat how to sympathize with him -
The afternoon after you left here, my brother and I, very suddenly decided to go to Epsom and Barnstead, to visit an uncle at E - and a school mate of mine, at the latter place. We left home about two o'clock, and arrived at uncle's residence, at six in the evening. At three o'clock, Wednesday afternoon, we started for Barnstead, where we found ourselves after a pleasant ride of about 15 miles - Brother Ge intended to return home Thursday, and leave me to come by stage, but the storm prevented his returning until Friday and in consequence of this, I thought it better for me to come home with him, - So we were both back again Friday night. We had long contemplated this little journey, and have finally accomplished it. My father was once settled in Epsom, and it is my native place.
Since I came home, I have been rather more busy than usual, in household matters. Mother and I are having considerable to do for brother, before he goes away, which will be in a week or two. - Geo. has been papering and whitewashing the room we live in, and I helped him about it, all I could. We are just nicely through with it.
Completed

March 16 - My letters are often somewhat in the journal style - I seldom finish one with a single date, especially when at home.
This is a very clear and beautiful day, and I have just been out to enjoy its sunshine, but it is not very pleasant walking, for the snow is rapidly taking its departure, and it is, of course, rather wet - I was quite glad to get back to the house.
I have engaged to teach a small school about two miles away, which is to commence the 20th of May, and continue 10 weeks, and perhaps a week or two longer. I thought of your advice to me, when I gave my affirmative answer, but this is so near home, that father and mother seemed to favor it, and on the whole I think it better for me to take it. -- Mrs. Parker and Mrs. Chase called here last Sunday - Mrs. P - came to know if I would teach a private school in Goffstown, before the summer term commenced. I hardly think, however, they will succeed in obtaining sufficient scholars, and I rather hope they will not; though it would be a very pleasant school for me - I think I should enjoy it.
- I hope you may realize fully all the happiness that you have been imagining. I almost tremble when I think what I have said and done - not that I regret it, or would retract one word; for it is all
Completed

A. Goffstown 
April 6, 1850

                                                                                                            Goffstown, April 6, 1849-             
                                                                                          

My dear friend,-
My first duty this morning shall be to commence a reply to your good, kind letter. As my date tells you, I am at Goffstown, and this day will close the third week of my school here. The very day I mailed my letter to you, I received a line from G- stating that efforts to obtain scholars had been successful, and desiring me to commence school the next week Tuesday. ( teach 19) Accordingly, I came hither, and began with 28 scholars,- the number is now increased to 38. There have been 41 different ones. This is twice the number I expected, or cared to have, - but probably some of the older ones will leave, as the farmer's spring work advances - Spring seemed early here, when this week commenced - the ground was almost entirely bare, and in some places the grass began to look green - but we have since had quite a snow storm. Not very much, however, now remains on the ground,- but the travelling is very rough
April 16. 1850
Written up the left side:
I expect school here will close the 10 day of hay - I shall board at three more places probably - Mr. Plummer Hadley's, Mr. George Perkins, and Mr. Luther Hadley's. A.
Completed

and bad - neither sleighing nor wheeling - A wonder time could not be, for school - but the scholars have been very regular thus far - more so than I had any idea they would be, at this season.
I am boarding now, at Mr. Brooks Hadey's. This is the house nearest to school - I may be here all the time, but when I came, I expected to board at three or four places - The travelling is such, that it is better for me to be near - They are so kind as to carry me, even this short distance, some of the time - My school is pleasant, and I am much interested in it - O how great a teacher's responsibility - Certainly no one more needs aid which Earth can never afford - I never felt this more, and I do hope I may be the means of doing some good, not merely to the minds, but to the precious, immortal souls of those with whom I daily mingle - But it is almost nine o'clock, and I must hie me away to my school room duties - I have some lessons to look over a little this morning-
(Evening.) My task is done, for the day and for the week, - and now I come to talk again with you. I did hope to have gone home to night - to spend the Sabbath, but am obliged to relinquish the idea. Mother wrote me yesterday, that Father would
Completed

come for me next Friday, as there will be no school next Saturday.
I was very much interested in your account of the little band of Christians at Milo and their meetings. A blessing must attend them, if they continue to persevere amidst so much to discourage - may they never be" weary in well doing" - I think I never before heard Mr. Willy preach as well as now. Perhaps his many trials have proved blessings in disguise - The people have been making some extra effort to retain him, and I presume he does not now think of leaving.
There is, at present, a vacation in the Sabbath School. Miss Jameson's class, however, continue their recitations, - and one other class, - of little girls. Mrs. Blaisdell has taken Miss Jameson's place since she left town.
I have just been writing a negative reply to a letter, received yesterday, from Lockport, Ills. containing a request to me to return, and take charge of the same school I left - two years since - Perhaps you will see the letter sometime, so I'll not write much about it.-
I was sorry to know that your brother was no better - but how pleasant it is for you, and
Completed

your friends, that he endures what must be a great affliction, with so much fortitude. I do hope he will yet be fully restored.
Miss Cook, the young lady who had been sick so long - of whom you heard us speak when you were last at D- died just three weeks since. It is just three weeks to day, since I assisted in arraying for the tomb, her lifeless body, - the frail casket - whence a priceless jewel had so recently departed - It was the first time I ever aided in a duty so mournful, and I hope it did me good - I should be sorry if it did not - Death never before seemed to me so solemn a reality - Miss C- was uniformly cheerful, through her sickness, and seemed happy and resigned, to the last moment - she took her Father's hands just before she died, and said to him, "Father, I am going, and I'm willing" - I have thought many times since, how full of meaning were those words.
I am reading "Washington and His Generals" now, but I make slow progress - find very little time to read.
You recollect, perhaps that Jack Frost assailed my rose bush, a number of times last Winter, and made it look very disconsolate - I wish you could see it now - it has two beautiful little buds -
I had almost forgotten to tell you that I had a nice ride in the cars to Manchester, about a week since I enjoyed it much - there were 52 persons in the car that morning, I believe -
I need not tell you that I should be happy to see you, or, if this may not be at present; to hear from you again -
Yours ever-
Antoinette-
Completed

A.B.P. to I.S.M.           Dunbarton N.H.
April 27. 1850

                                                                                                                                       Dunbarton, April 27. 1850.

My dear friend,-

                        This delightful Saturday afternoon, I am enjoying at home - in my own quiet - Dunbarton. I came from Goffstown early this morning - had a very pleasant ride. Yesterday and to day have seemed really like Spring. more so than any days we have had before - so warm and sunny - and then the grass being to look quite green, in some places. How pleasant it is to see so many tokens of returning Spring. This morning I listened to the joyous songs of the sweet little birds, till, I felt almost as light - and happy as the merry little creatures themselves. You speak of its being very cold where you have been. It has been so here, until within a few days. When I was at home two weeks ago, it was snowy and very windy all day Saturday, and cold as winter. I rode down to school Monday morning in a sleigh. Mother was then quite unwell. Her eyes have been, for two or three weeks so much inflamed, that she has been unable to use them at all, but I find her now much better, though not well. I have decided since I came home, to close school at

Milo May 6, 1850
[left-hand side] Many thanks for the privilege of knowing your name. A.
Completed

G., next week. Father and Mother think I shall need two weeks of rest, before commencing my Summer school, and I am quite willing to take them, myself - so I shall probably be at home in just one week from now, to remain two weeks. - and myself and parents, would be very happy to receive a visit from you, at that time, unless your arrangements are such that you cannot leave conveniently. We should be very glad to see you at any time, and my school will be so near home that I shall be at home every week, and oftener, when there is anything to call me.

  Of course, we shall not expect to see you at present if you decide to go to New Brunswick - you say I must advise you. Well, I will as well as I can. I should like to have you do just as you think will be for the best. It would be very pleasant - could you be located in New Hampshire. I have hoped it might be so, and it may be yet - but if duty seems to call you elsewhere, I shall be satisfied.
 You ask how I should like to live, for a time, in New Brunswick. The idea is not an unpleasant one to me. I could be happy in almost any situation, could I feel that I was useful, or doing good to any one. I think one ought to be willing to go where there seems the greatest prospect of usefulness. I believe I have identified my interests with yours, so much that in whatever situation Providence shall place you, if you are happy, I can be so too.
-- --- I believe I have now but 31 regular scholars and consequently my labor in school, is not as wearisome
Completed

as at first. I was at Mr. Parker's last week, and shall be there one or two days more. Fanny is a dear girl, one could not help loving her. We had a very pleasant walk together, last Friday, after school, went to the woods in search of May flowers. we found an abundance of leaves and buds, but no a single blossom - so we loaded ourselves with evergreen instead.

             It was Mrs. Frances Chase, who called here with Mrs. Parker. I think her a very pleasant lady - should suppose she had considerable energy and resolutions, - though I have hardly seem her enough to form any opinion correctly. Neither have I become much acquainted with the other Mrs. Chase. Mrs. Parker has another boarder now - a Mr. Johnson came there last week. Mr. Parker's family often speak of you, with interest.
  {S.S. Sabbath} I have been at meeting all day. The weather has been pleasant and a good many people were out. Since I came home, I have been thinking of those little meetings at Milo and wondering whether you had read a sermon from the National Preacher, to day. It seems you are supplying the place of a minister, now, to the interesting little band of Christians there: I am glad this opportunity is afforded, in which you may so greatly benefit yourself and others. I hope success will attend the efforts making to secure preaching this summer, and that it may prove the means of the salvation of many.
 Last week we received the best of intelligence, from relatives residing in Bridgewater and Westboro', Mass. In those towns, and other in the vicinity of them, God's
Completed

spirit, with its "still small voice," is working wonders. Five dear cousins are already hoping that they have found the Savior. This is good news to us. -There seems, at present, to be no special interest - here, in regard to this most important of all subjects, but we hope there are blessings yet in store for us.

  {Monday morning} It rains very fast indeed this morning. Perhaps it will cease before eight oclock comes - we must start about that time for Goffstown, but if it does not we must make the best of it: we can "carry our sunshine with us". Father is going with me. 
                The summer school I have taken will continue ten or eleven weeks. I know not, definitely, which. It is my intention not to make farther engagements of the kind, without your approval.
               Would you be stationed at New Brunswick, how long shall you probably remain? If you go there, I shall feel quite anxious to hear about your situation, and how you are pleased with it. I hope your brother's cheerfulness, will not forsake him, when you leave he will, of course, feel the loss of your society. It seems your mothers spends most of her time at Milo. I should love to hear more about her, and your sisters, - think they must be good.
  Your letter reached me the 25th - many thanks for it - and may I not hope for another soon; - Father and mother send their kind regards to you, with many good wishes for your prosperity.
                                                            Yours ever.
                                                                              Antoinette.
Completed

Dunbarton May. 22. 1850

                                                                                                                                        Dunbarton, Mayy 22, 1850.

My dear friend,

              This day public duties are over, and, with much pleasure I commence a reply to your last kind letter. This is the third day of school, and I have been very happy, thus far. I could not desire more obedient - or affectionate pupils. It almost five me pain sometimes to see how hard they strive to give me pleasure. I have only one or two scholars with whom I was unacquainted - most of them, I have known for years. The recitations besides reading, spelling and the usual general exercises are Geography, grammar, Arithmetic and Algebra. There will a class in Whelpley's Compend, as soon as books can be obtained, - find my labors very much less fatiguing than at Goffstown; - school at G. - closed very pleasantly. We had a number of visitors the last afternoon. The school room was decorated
Completed

with masses evergreen, and May Flowers quite tastefully arranged.

 This has been a glorious day - a day when, if ever a teacher would wish all her charge to play truant, that she too might be free to roam. But this bright sun, which make everything without so perfectly enchanting, makes the school rooms very cheerful also. After all, I do not think it surprising in the last that little children should love the fresh air, and the green fields better. I think my scholars are some of the very best. I love them all very much, already.
  My short vacation passed very pleasantly. Home is a dear place, is it not? And mine seems dearer than ever. I believe home, and friends too, become, by absences, doubly precious.
   Monday morning, father and mother left home to be absent two weeks, on a journey to Westboro' Mass. to visit mothers relatives, so our house is at present deserted. Fanny goes to school, and boards with one of our neighbors.
          It seems you have preaching now at Milo. The parents of Mr. Temple once passed two or three days at Dunbarton. They are very devoted christians. I never
Completed

saw two persons who seemed to live and breathe so much in the very atmosphere of heaven, as they. Their countenances wore the expression of that "perfect peace" which those alone enjoy whose "minds are stayed on God." - Hoe long is the vacation - and will you be again destitute when Mr. G. leaves?  Is there a Sabbath School in Milo? Ours in D has just been reorganized, and an effort is making, with considerable success, to increase the number of attendants. O if those who absent themselves, only knew the privileges, would they not avail themselves of it: I never valued the S.S. so much as since I came home from Illinois. I have just been reading the last Report of the Boston Ladies' Society for the Promotion of Education at the West. Every line is full of interest. Those teachers must be happy - how can they help it - usefulness is happiness.

    It is sad to hear that your sick brother seems so rapidly sinking - hope you will be able to remain with him longer, since he seems so much to require your company and aid.
   I think you gave me quite a full description of your sister Lucy, in the short compass of two words. It
Completed

would give me pleasure to see her and become acquainted with your friends. Have you more than one half sister?

  Last Friday { May 17 } was my 21 birth day. It seems sad to know that so many years of life has gone, and so very little is done towards accomplishing the great end for which life was given. Perhaps it would be better to forget the past, and press forward. It seems but a day, since I looked forward to this age as far, very far in the future, and now it is really here. Friday I enjoyed a pleasant ride with father to Concord.
  {May 23} This is a lovely evening, and I have had a fine walk since school. The fruit trees are in full blossom, and the trees and fields are both so beautifully green that it is a feast to behold them. Without doubt, you have as much such beauty to look upon as I have, but one can hardly think or talk of anything else, when Spring first comes. What a bright and beautiful world this is, and how very much we have, for which to thank the glorious Giver of every good and perfect gift.
  Perhaps you are now ministering to the wants of your afflicted brother. -May I ask if you consider him immediately dangerous?
                    It is late, and I must stop. I shall hope to receive another letter ere long. Accept this from
                                                                                                                                 Your Antoinette.
Completed

Antoinette
June 12 1850 Dunbarton

                                                                                                                                                    Dunbarton June 10. 1850

My dear friend,

                         When I came home last Saturday night, I found your welcome letter waiting for me, and was very happy indeed to hear from you. Still watching with your sick brother, and he apparently no better. It must be painful to you all to see him so weak and helpless. I rejoice with you that his mind is in so desirable a state. This is consolation indeed. It must be a very great trial to your brother thus to be shut out from the active enjoyment of life. But how delightful is it, in the midst of affliction, to be able to look up, with confidence, to that precious Heavenly Friend who knows just what we need, and who can sustain under every trial. He sends upon us sickness, and He too can make us well again. Soon will life's toilsome journey  be over, and then for the Christian is in store - a rest, a home, and what a home - O glorious
Completed

reward for all the suffering of this short pilgrimage.

    It must be a great change in your life to be so constantly in doors. Is patience never tested, and are you not often wearied with so much anxiety and care? I think of you very often and pray that He who had promised to be a "present help"  would guide and bless you always. I hope your own health will not suffer in consequence and that you may all speedily be made glad by the return of health and strength to your brother. What you wrote of him reminds me of my mother's illness two years since. Father was away the first three weeks, while there was most to be done for her, and no one at home but Jenny and me. When she was able to sit up, we had a chair with wheels prepared for her use. But the fractured bones healed very rapidly after they began to mend. We think the accident was a benefit to her general health, because the cough which has troubled her for many years has been better ever since.
     Father and mother had a very rainy
Completed

time for their journey - only two pleasant days during the two weeks of their absence   but they reached home as soon as we expected them and we were of course very glad to see them. What a miserable place this world would be without friends to love - a wilderness - without a flower.

  I thank you for the information respecting your brothers and sisters contained in your last. I should love to know them all - and I felt, after reading your letter, almost as if I had seen them.  You must enjoy much in each others society. You are not as widely separated as are many families.

{12th June} A delightful morning this - Dunbarton is "in its glory" now. - about - two miles north from home, I find flowers every night and morning as I go to and from school, and we have fresh ones in this school room every day. The scholars take great pleasure in bringing them; and I certainly would not, for anything, deprive my school room of the cheerfulness they give it. They are sweet companions. It seems sometimes as if they were living, thinking beings like ourselves. O, I do love them. I have studied Botany a little, and
Completed

should like to persue it farther. I once spent about two months in the family of Dr. Colby, now of Salem, Mass. but who then lived in Keene, N.H.  He was preparing a collection of pressed flowers, for some literary Institute at the West, and passed much of his time in collecting and analysing , while I was there I think I learned more of Botany there, than when studying it at school. That was five or six  years since. I hope to be able to give more time to it this summer. But I very often intend to do much more than I accomplish. I find so many duties that must be attended to, that my progress in study or reading is like the plodding of a snail, - but it is useless to be discouraged, so I hope on.

    We have Compositions every week in school and this is the day for them to be read. {Wednesday}.
    At three oclock this afternoon, we have a recess of ten minutes, and then come together in the form of a Sewing Circle. We are at work for the "Home for the Friendless" in New York. So few of us, we cannot accomplish a great deal, but our mite will perhaps be acceptable. I am fully occupied in cutting and preparing work for the busy little fingers and they enter into it, with so much enthusiasm that our "Circle" is becoming quite a interesting affair to me.
  So you expect your sister at Wisconsin, will remain

[left-hand side] My parents deliver a remembrance to you. A.
Completed

A. Dunbarton July 8

                                                                                                                                                    Dunbarton  July 8, 1850.

My dear friend

                    Had you been here this morning you would have found me busy about the usual employment of Monday - rub-rub-rubbing. My mother had been so unwell, for three or four weeks, that we have endeavored to finish the washing, for the week, before I go away to school - so that my Monday mornings are no leisure season for me.   - but washing is complete now, and a little corner of time is left, before I must go to my week's duties which I improve in writing.  Your good letter. was received with much pleasure, last Saturday. I had been looking for it a little longer than usual, and it was the more welcome. Very happy to learn that your brother is no worse and that your sister had so far recovered her health.
       I wish I could tell you that my dear mother's health was good but this is far from being the case. I have very little

Milo, July  1850
[left-hand side and top] "fairest in the youngest" "and yields the sweetest fruit". Is little Lizzie included in the two of your sister's children you mention?  I have a class of six little boys in the Sabbath school. O, how much a teacher ought to do to lead the young and tender mind to Christ.  He is just the friend they need to keep them from this wicked world. And my own dear brothers are growing up and going forth into the world, to meet its thousand snares, without- this Friend.
I must tell you one thing about my rosebush. Every bud with one exception unfolded on the Sabbath. Is that not a little singular? We think it teaches us a very sweet lesson.
I think you must be very happy with your brother notwithstanding you must be indoors so constantly. I should like to see a copy of that "Cedar Grove Botany" when it appears. My scholars are very much interested, at present, in the language of flowers. This furnishes a very pleasant theme for conversation in the morning before school, and I hope it is somewhat profitable also.
Father and Mother send love to you. Father says it is probably you have recieved a letter from Esq. Steele in this. He told Father some days since, he intended to write. But I must stop. Yours very truly, Antoinette.
Completed

expectation that she will ever be well again. She is much more feeble than she was six months since. It may be the warm weather has an effect. I hope it will prove so. No one is at home - father, mother and sister Jane. Brother George is a farmer's boy, this summer, and Henry we suppose is in Haverhill. though we have heard nothing from him for about four weeks. He then wrote that we might expect him home in less than a week. He has not come; and we are quite anxiously waiting to know the reason - brother thinks he must have written, and the letter has, for some reason, failed to reach us.

                I thought I should nearly finish this letter at home this morning but school time came apace. Now I am seated in my school room - in the pedagogical chair, - not surround by pupils, for they have all said good night and are gone  - and my spirit can "talk with them," unheeded I should love to have you look in upon me here some afternoon, as you mentioned, though I could not promise 

[left-hand side] We are thinking it is possible you may be back in New Hampshire before a long time since. There is a prospect that the Railroad will advance - unless you feel that your sick brother demands your time. We would feel very much the loss of your society.
Completed

very much to interest you. I am sure you would not be much delighted with the appearance of the poor old brown school house. Neither inside or outside  ever came in contact with a paint brush but notwithstanding its appearance is so uninviting, it is a very comfortable place, and the bright eyes, and faces beaming with intelligence and intellect, make me forget  the dingy walls. It contains a stove, which we had occasion to use constantly for the first three weeks, but we have two chairs, one of which seems to be a relic of the olden time, a blackboard of course, though of rather limited dimensions - a water pail and dipper, washbowls and towels. You will perceive we have the comforts we need, thought not much that is ornamental, save the flowers, which still find a place but the roses are fast passing away & when they are gone, I am fearful our flowers will be almost minus.  The school house is just at the foot of a hill and there
Completed

are a good many apple trees  near it. It seems to be a favorite retreat for the birds - they sing most delightfully all around us in the morning.

  But I'll say no more of the school house, lest I have room for nothing besides. I have noticed it more prominently than I had any intention of doing.
      The Merrimack Co. Conference of churches met here two weeks since. There were 19 minister present and the meetings which were very interesting, continued two days Tuesday & Wednesday. I left school & attended. No revivals were reported, but a general good state of feeling among the churches and occasional conversions. We can but hope these meetings will be the means of good here. Our Sabbath congregations are unusually attentive and solumn. 
            Mr. Will sees at last - among his people, appearances which must gladden his heart, as they do the hearts of every Christian. There have been several hopeful conversions there - three or four heads of families among the number. The interest seems now increasing. Stillness characterizes the work. Good Mr Willy  - How long he has labored among that people to human appearance in vain.  May God bless his labor yet more and more. When he pleases, you can cause the word of truth to take effect. 
   It is very pleasant to tear of such a state of things in Milo. - hope it will continue. How delightful it is to see those in the morning of lips, choosing their Savior for their friend. ?Piety is always lovely, but I often think it is
Completed

A. Dunbarton N.H.
July 31, 1850

                                                                                            Dunbarton, July 31, 1850.

My dear friend, 

                  Your letter came last evening, and was very welcome. You must be very busily employed. I fear you have too much to think of for your health and comfort. You must be weary and in need of rest, when the day is gone. I hope you will not be obliged to do anything which will deprive you of health- it is such a treasure. So much care is wearing to one's health and spirits. But "life's cares are comforts; such by Heaven designed,- he that has now, must make them or be wretched." Is not this true?- although such comforts may be so abundantly heaped upon us, so to be burdensome.
  My brother Henry is no better. There is occasionally a day when he seems more comfortable, but the next day is almost sure to bring something new and unfavorable. I commenced school again the day after you were here, but I never found it so difficult to give my school my thoughts before; have been home every other day, thus far.

Newberry N.H.   Aug. 2, 1850
Completed

Mother says she feels as well as before Henry was sick. She is favored with very good help indeed. If H. should be worse, I shall leave school again. Last week was the first which has seemed long to me.

  I hope ere this you have heard good tidings from your friends in Maine. We are all anxious to know if your brother continues to gain.
  Now I'll tell you how we all felt after you left us. Dear mother feared lest she had not been quite gentle enough in what she said, and thought sometimes, that perhaps she ought not to have said anything.   She hopes you will forgive, as she intended good. Father made the single remark that he thought you were placed in rather peculiar circumstances. Should he say more, I'll "plead the case" to the best of my ability. I felt rather badly because I imagined you did - and then I thought - if you had done wrong I had at least helped you to do so, or had been in some measure the cause of it. And besides, I, naughty child, was so thoughtless as to tell you the story of one of my western trials, without once thinking it might then trouble you at all to hear it. Now I hope you will forget all about it, unless it may be remembered to good. Perhaps the occurrence
Completed

may teach us all a useful lesson in some way.

  But don't forget to come and see us again, as soon as you can, for we all wish to see you, and I more than all the rest. I should love to have you see a little more of Dunbarton, while the trees & the fields are so beautiful. But we know that must be difficult - for you to be away.
  The weather here is rather unpleasant. It rains almost every day. I have thought of you and wondered what you do when it rains. Do you always find shelter?
   Our little Sewing Circle met yesterday. Our work progresses very finely. The ladies in this neighborhood are aiding us considerably. The little boys are about making some book marks as their part - they enter into it very zealously.
   My youngest scholar, a little girl not quite four years old, has just come in to my rooms with a morning tribute of flowers - it is no new thing. She is a frequent visitor, and gives me much pleasure. I have seen a number of flowers that were new to me this Summer. I had quite a long walk yesterday morning, before
Completed

school with some of my scholars, and enjoyed it, as I always do.  This earth is so fair.  It has sometimes seemed sad to me to think of ever leaving it.  sin only mars its beauty, and what a sad and humbling thought it is that  we must always, while we live here, be sinners.  We may strive and fight against sin and yet it will cleave to us.  We must  carry about with us sinful, wicked, hearts as long as we live.  But God "knoweth our frame and remembereth that we are dust".  Through Christ we may conquer, and hope to find in Heaven where no sin can enter, a rich reward for all.  
Now comes the best.  I have reserved it for the last.  When I went home a little more than a week ago, Henry said to me "Nettie, I mean to be a Christian.  I am determined to be for Christ.  After I had replied, he said "if I always feel so, this sickness will be a blessing.  It will not be for naught. "   We are all rejoicing in this decision, and hope he will live to prove it real.  He says he had been thinking more than usual of the subject, for a number of weeks before he was sick.  I know life only is the test. but we can but hope, and feel that these impressions will continue.

The clock tells me that school time has come.  so I must stop.  My best wishes are yours for success and happiness.  Hope to hear from you as soon as your numerous duties will allow, and I hope I can say that Henry is better when I write again, but we fear he will be sick a long time.  

So ever yours
Antoinette.
Completed

Home Aug. 17, 1850
My dear friend, 
When I came home from school last night, I fully intended to have mailed a reply to your last, Thursday but night had come, and these are the first moments I have been able to command.  Now that Henry is sick, I find many duties, when I come home, that I am very happy to be able to discharge, and to day has been an unusually busy one.  My brother has been very, very sick since I wrote.  His fever assumed the typhoid form, and for a number of days, we had not the least expectation of his recovery. His physicians told us that all the hope they could give us , was the fact that he was alive.  He is now more comfortable but whether really any better, we hardly know.  He is very weak- not able to sit up at all.  He lies most of the time as if he were asleep. taking no notice of anything about him. He takes some nourishment, and usually seems to relish it very well.  Dr. Moore of Concord, has been to see him, and also
Completed

Dr. Nichols of Danvers, Mass.  The last named came to this town to visit a sick relative, and Father sent to him to call and see H.  Dr. Chadbounne of Concord is coming out next week.  It does seem very strange that he does not gain [unclear] , he seems, for one day, to be better, but something is sure to take place immediately, to discourage our hopes.  I have been out of school another week, while H. was sickest.  Have now but one week longer.  My brother still seems to be in a very quite and happy state of mind.  Father often talks with him, when he is sufficiently roused to enter into conversation.  He still seems decided as a Christian and willing to leave his all in the hands of our kind Heavenly Father, feeling that ' He doeth all things well".  It is very hard for me to realize that the pale and sunken face I see, is really my brother Henry.  It is so strange for him to come home sick, as he has usually been so strong and well.  It will be nine weeks tomorrow, since he was taken ill.  

(18. Sabbath)  Brother is not quite so well today.  Yesterday afternoon two gentlemen, who worked and boarded with him at Havenhill, came to see him.  The excitement of seeing them, though he saw them but a few moments, was more than he could well endure, but we hope it will not permanently injure him.  We are have one of our most beautiful
Completed

sunsets to night.  It seems the more pleasant because it is the Sabbath. Probably you have been at Newport to day.  Does the preacher there improve, or do you still prefer his predecessor?  Do you not feel almost as much wearied on the Sabbath as on other days?  I do not perceive that you have a moment of leisure.  I hope some one of those assistants of yours, will soon be able to relieve you of care and labor as much as you did Mr Chase.  Though perhaps you would not be so ready to relinquish your duties to another as was he.

 I have been at church all day to day Mother has not been at all since H. was sick and one of us always stay at home with him.  George stayed to day.  O these precious Sabbaths and these sermons what a privilege to be permitted to enjoy them, and how important that they be improved.  

(Monday morn) You will think it takes me a long time to write, and as it has this time, for I can find only a few moment at once.  I have considerable to think of this week besides home and friends as it is the last week of school, and the examining committee came to see us on Friday.  This is a clear, bright morning every thing is lovely, and it makes ones heart bound in gladness to go out or even to look out. Poor Henry cannot enjoy it.  I am sitting by him and he is talking wildly, most of the
Completed

time, for a day or two, he has been more wandering than ever. He has been bereft of reason, a great part of the time, in this respect, last week. It seems very strange that he should lie in this state so long. How glad I am that I can be at home after this week. It is hard to think of going away this morning.

      When Mr. Steele was negotiating with you for your services, he incidentally mentioned to father, that he was embarrassed by the restrictions of the Directors, who had limited the salary to be allowed, to a less sum than you thought suitable. Father feels a little curiosity to know how you adjusted the matter, and would like to have me ask you to mention in your next, if you have no objection.
        Father and mother send love. Brother H. has spoken of you a number of time since you were here. He says "nobody ever kept the flies away so well." But I must close this rambling letter, from your
                                                                       Antoinette

[upside down at top]Sunapee, N.H. via Newport & Newbury Aug. 23, 1850
[upside down at bottom] Antoinette Dunbarton N.H.

                                      Aug. 17 - 1850
Completed

Home. Aug. 25, 1850.

My dear friend,

                   I sit down to write with a sad and heavy heart. God has taken my oldest brother, my precious Henry away from us. This is no longer his house, but we hope he is gone to a happier home in heaven. I can almost say, this is my first real sorrow. Death never came so near to me before, but our "Father" has done it, and we cannot murmur.
        He died this morning about eight o'clock, after lying about four hours apparently insensible to everything about him. He did not, until yesterday, relinquish the hope that he would recover. O how unexpected this affliction! It is very hard for me to think if it as reality. It seems as if I were writing a falsehood, when I say that Henry is dead - my hand almost refuses to write that sad word. Truly "God moves in a mysterious way," His wonders to perform." But we know that he will one day, "make
Completed

it plain". we shall know why He has done thus, & see, and feel that this is the very chastisement we needed. O! I do hope we shall all profit by this trial. How dreadful it is to think of the possibility of its being misimproved. I never felt more sensibly that - 

                            "Tis not the whole of life to live,
                             Nor all of death to die."

And how true it is that the Christian's hope takes away the "sting of Death." Had we no hope that dear H. is safe in a better land, how much greater would be the affliction. It is so pleasant to think we may meet again. But it is late, and I'll stop, for to night: How much we should enjoy your society for a few days now, or even a few hours, - but it is a privilege to talk to you as I am now doing.

 {Aug. 26 - Evening} The last sad duties are performed - we have followed our loved H. to his last resting place & left him there. He will not more return to us. O how can I ever believe it? It is all mist - the events of the past week seem all a vision - a dream and I tremble lest this impression they seem to have made, should die away
Completed

as does the vessel's "prow" from the "parted wave." We earnestly hope that the death of one so young & vigorous, may be blessed not only to ourselves, but to all - particularly the youth of D__. He who has sent this application, knows how to overrrule it for his own glory. The funeral was this afternoon at four o'clock. A very large number of people were present.

      Dear H. continued in a very calm and happy state of mind, as long as he was able to tell us of his feelings. He was delirious much of the time, but every lucid moment seemed to be employed in prayer. Once when father was talking with him, he said he should like to recover - and be a living, active, working Christian, but if God chose otherwise, he felt that it would work out for him a far more exceeding and eternal weight of glory.

{22} My school is finished - closed a little sooner than I expected when I wrote last. I came home often to spend the night, but it was still very trying to my feeling to be away so much - mother says she enjoyed the greatest privilege, for she was with H. most during his sickness. Her health is about as usual, except fatigue. Father
Completed

is also somewhat worn out.  
I will close this and mail it to day, as we think you will like to hear what has taken place as soon as possible

We are all anxious to hear of the health of you brother hope he is still recovering.  Father and mother send love.

Yours truly

Antoinette

Dunbarton NH
