                                                                    Dunbarton, Sept, 11, 1850

My dear friend,

 Your last kind letter was received and read with unusual interest.  Since then my time has been very full occupied. Mother has been almost sick, and we have had much company.  After my brother's death, all the days seemed like Sabbaths it was quite a task for us to engage in our usual duties, but that feeling is wearing away.  I do hope other impressions, made by that event and more desirable to be retained will not as speedily depart. and I cannot think they will.  Another world does seem nearer, and tho paths that leads us thither seems brighter, and this earth too, seems fairer than ever.  It does not appear the dark wilderness which some, who have known sorrow, feel it to be.  I know not why.  I should love to think ( if I dared;) it is because I see more than ever before, God in all things.  

Now that one loved brother "is not" because God has 
[written along side]
Your brother is recovering, I hope your own health will not suffer from over- exertion.  I think you deserve a few hours of leisure every week at least. 
Very truly Antoinette. 

Newbury, N.H. Sept. 13, 1850
Completed

taken him. I find my heart clings more and more closely to my only remaining one, and I am very happy to tell you that George thinks he has come to the full determination to live a Christian life, and we do hope he has indeed chosen the good part. O may his future life be spent in doing good, and furnish, constantly, new evidence that this is a genuine work of grace. What more, or better could we desire for him? Surely we have abundant reason for gratitude to Heaven.

   I have been reading to day a long account of the proceedings of the General Association. It must be interesting to hear Mr. Haddard  talk of the Nestorians.  I really feel much interest in that little band of Christians. They furnish an example, in many respects worth imitation, by the professed followers of Christ everywhere.  The writer of the notice refered to, speaks very highly of Dr. Dwight's performance, but rather disparagingly of that of Pres. Lord. The peculiar views of the latter, must be very cheerless & discouraging to those laboring to convert the world.
   {Eve} I have just returned from a delightful ride with my dear father and mother, and I did enjoy it so very much that I can do no otherwise than
Completed

sit down directly and write about it. Perhaps it seemed pleasanter, because I have not been to ride for some time before. It came just at twilight, that sweetest part of the day, to me, - and the sky and clouds- but I'll not try to describe them. It would be utterly useless. I'll just say they were very, very beautiful. They looked just as they have many times, without doubt, when you have seen and admired, - and then the air, it does one good to inhale such sweetness. And the kind words and acts of the people too. we called on one family whose greeting thrice repaid us, and when returning, a young lady of our own acquaintance, came out to meet us, and deposited in our carriage a nice large pumpkin, and some fresh flowers, she said for Antoinette - but I expect it was all for my parent's sake.  Who could help being happy? It would be wicked not to be, and as much so, to forget whence come alike the flower and the thorn. To Him be thanks for both.

 This much for my ride. I cannot tell much about it after all. I believe I can feel it, better than I can describe it.
   Since I last write, Summer has departed, and
Completed

the chilly winds we have occasionally, remind us that Autumn is here. We have had rain, frequent and abundant, so that, since the grain was gathered, "the sear, the yellow leaf" is hardly visible anywhere  about us, at present.    

 If you have showers as often as we, those instruments must, ere this, have become quite thoroughly acquainted with your coats. Mother thinks she shall suggest an India Rubber covering, made on purpose, to take the place of the garments.
 I have no school to occupy my thoughts now. It seemed rather strange at first, as usual, but I did not mind it as much as I generally do, because I have had so much else to take my attention. The school agent, in the District, wished to know whether if they would allow me three or four weeks in which to rest, I would return for a private school. Since that, another school has been proffered, of a similar character.  The visiting Committee and a number of the people of the District were present, the last afternoon of my school. You will recollect I had but 12 scholars, but notwithstanding the small number,  the exercises were not completed until five minutes past five o'clock. I intended to have been through before four, but the Committee had very many questions to ask, which, of course, detained us. But the examination never passed with more comfort and pleasure to me. I shall always love those scholars - they have been so good & studious. It required very little effort, on my part, to govern my school.
    We are just enjoying some very fine early apples which our own farm produced. I wish you could share them with us - could I send some in a letter, they should be forthcoming. Father says "you can, but it would be a very awkward letter."
      We are all very glad to hear that you still hope
Completed

Home. Oct. 1 1850

My dear friend,

       This is a lovely morning, and I have been wondering if Oct. has brought you as beautiful a day. How delightful and invigorating are these cool and sunny morning - one cannot be sad. And sometimes when there is so much loveliness to behold, it seems too much for one heart to contain. I have just been thinking how pleasant it would be if you were here now, to help me enjoy the beauty that is all around.
  Do not your situation and occupation, afford many opportunities to gratify a taste for Natural History? - though perhaps you are obliged to be so busy that you cannot stop to examine & enjoy what is to be seen. I was reading, a day or two since, a few lines, describing the emotions of one who loves Nature, so perfectly, that I believe I must write it for you in the words of the author. I thought of you when I read it. It is this - "He feels as if he grew in the grass, and flowers, and groves; as if he stood on yonder distant mountain tops, conversing with clouds, or sublimely sporting among their imaged precipices, caverns , and ruins, He flows in that river, chafes in its cascades, smiles in the water-lilies, frisks in the fishes. He is sympathetic with every bird &
Completed

seems to feel the sentiment that prompts the song of each." - Is it not fine! And have you not felt it many a time, while rambling over mountain and valley and hill? That mountain you wrote about - I really feel quite interested in it, and the dwelling so very near it, with the good people within. I can almost see the whole establishment.

     Oct. 2 Here we are - mother and I - quietly seated in our kitchen, which is home to us both, at least in the forenoon. We have been sewing, and studying History, by turns - till just now I thought I should like writing better. I must tell you something about the good meetings we have had. Week before last, Mr. Cordley, the minister at Hopkinton, with five delegates from his church, came over and passed two days  - Wednesday & Thursday. The forenoon of each day, was spent in visiting from house to house, and conversing with the people on religious subjects, and in the afternoon and evening, Mr. Cordley preached. These meetings were very well attended and much interest was manifested. Since that week, quite a number have been here to converse with father about their souls, and seven individuals have expressed a determination to be for Christ. Father has appointed a regular meeting for those who wish to converse with him. It is held in his study, or Tuesday evening.
  It is found that many have, for some weeks, been unusually thoughtful. The first one who expressed
Completed

hope, said her first impressions were received, while listening to the sermon on the sabbath after my brother died. I do hope we shall yet see still greater things. Three other persons have died within the last three weeks. These occurrences, reminding us so frequently how frail we are, seem to have made a deep impression on many minds. O may it be lasting. Then we shall indeed have cause to bless God even for afflictions. He does know what is best, and it is very, very sweet to trust our all with Him., to feel that we are safe - perfectly sage, always, because God will take care of us. He is indeed good and merciful, and let us love and praise Him more and more.

    Father, and five delegates from this church, are going to Hopkinton, week after next, - to return the visit we have received. It was at the request of this church that the delegation from H. came here, and they request the return.
     Is Mr. Simeon Burnham from Manchester one of your company? Some years since he taught school in this town, and my father is considerably acquainted with him. He learned, a few days since, that he was employed on the Central R.R.
   It is pleasant to hear that your brother is still better. I know you must feel anxious to see him.
   It is late and I have been sitting here alone, for some times. I must not write much longer.
   Did you know the pleasure your letter afforded, I do not believe you would think you relinquished the
Completed

"Coon Hunting," for naught, neither would you ask me to excuse it. I should be very sorry to excuse it from my company of letter treasures.

 But I do hope you will have an opportunity to go hunting, while in the region of that mountain, for I think it would be quite a relief to say good bye to dull care, and engage in such sport, for a time. How I should love to hear those creatures "whistle," it would seem almost as if I were back in Illinois.
   Don't you think you will someday before a long time, emerge from those mountain recesses, so effectually that Dunbarton will be the better for it? The inmates of a certain little cottage would be happy to welcome you, one little body in particular. But we all know that you are very busy indeed, and that it must be very difficult for you to be away. You are very kind to write so much. A letter always comes the very day I look for it. But I must stop, or father and mother will think me a naughty girl to write so late.
                                                                                           Very truly,  your
                                                                                          Antoinette

[upside down] Antoinette  Dunbarton, N.H.

                                   Oct. 1  1850.
Completed

Home. Nov. 1, 1850.

My dear friend,

               I do not know that I was ever in my life, more delighted to see a letter, than I was yesterday, when yours reached me. To day the truth, I had been feeling rather sadly, for I know that you were away from the vicinity of Bradford, and had heard incidentally that you had been at Goffstown & Manchester , and what had become of you I could not conceive. After we learned that the surveying had ceased above Henniker, we expected, for about a week, at every ringing of the door bell, you would enter; and then we began to think that you might have a Report, or Estimates, or something of the kind to occupy your time.  But now, the mystery is unraveled, and I ma just as happy as ever. I was at Manchester last Saturday with my brother, and thought a little of spending the Sabbath, but finally we decided to come home. I never once
Completed

suspected that you were there.

     I mailed a letter directed to Newbury, nearly two weeks since. Perhaps it has been remailed.
     I am sorry you were unable to see your sister in Boston, but if RailRoad matters terminate as you anticipate. you can see her at home, which will be much pleasanter. How sorry I am for your sick brother - you must be very anxious to see him, and I rejoice for your sake and his, that is seems probably you will ere long have an opportunity. Are you not tired of making Estimates? I should think you would be weary of so much head work. It is not surprising that your mind is "full of Rail Road" and I can sympathize a little for, many a time I have been able to think of nothing but school. I have often, on the Sabbath, found it next to impossible to give attention to the sermon. Before I was aware my thoughts would be entirely absorbed in some new plan for the coming week. It is indeed very disagreeable; but it must require, to avoid it, a mind most perfectly disciplined. I should think it next to impossible for a mind, naturally sensitive,
Completed

to be entirely free from this difficulty.

 And now, lest you will have no time to read a long letter, I will stop, hoping to see you as soon as next Saturday. I assure you it is much more difficult - to be patient when you are so near, than when I think of you as far away as Maine, or even Newbury.  We shall be very happy to see you, and I do hope you will be able to spend next Sabbath with us. Just think - father has not seen you since last March.
                                                                                                                          As ever, yours,
                                                                                                                          Antoinette.
Completed

Antoinette   Merrimack N.H.
Dec. 2. 4. 1850

                                                                                                                                    Merrimack, N.H. Dec. 2, 1850

My dear friend,

                      Here we are, brother George and I at "Merrimack Normal Institute. We came hither today, accompanied by father. The New Haven project resulted very much as you seemed to have anticipated. A letter reached us, last Thursday, the 28 of Nov. stating that Miss Bacon once had a class, to whom she listened, as we supposed, and whose reading she directed and regulated, and that she was now pursuing the same cause with a class in Boston. The next day father saw a gentleman who has been a teacher, and a pupil also, in this institution, who gave so flattering an account of everything connected with it, that we at once decided that it was the best place for us. The term commenced this day, so

Bangor, via Milo. Dec. 10, 1850
[left-hand side] This is Merrimack, Reed's Ferry, N.H.
Completed

brother and I, had just one day in which to prepare for ten weeks absence from our home, but we succeeded in making everything ready, left home about eight o'clock, took the cars at Goffstown and reached this place about half past eleven. It is one of the regulations, that those who intend to become members of the school. shall give previous intimations of it, otherwise they cannot be admitted, but the winter term is somewhat smaller than the others, and for this reason, and by making some little change in their arrangements we were admitted.

Dec. 4, I wrote only thus far yesterday for considerable of my time was "occupied in the school room, and besides it was, as every first day usually us, one of more or less confusion. But to day I can tell you that I am really delighted with the school. Mr. Russell and Mr. Ray, who are the Instructors and as the head of the Institute, seem to be just what
Completed

teachers ought to be. Not long since, I read a lecture which Mr. Russell delivered on the Teacher's duties in which he says that "every teacher should be a living Encyclopedia to his pupils." I think he is a most perfect example of this. I have heard him lecture twice already, and these lectures as well as each recitation show abundantly that he has a fund of information which very few if any can boast. No one can avoid being pleased with him.  My recitations at present - are in Etymology, Analysis of the Eng. Language, Rhetoric, History, & French, beside Reading and Elocution in which every member is expected to join. Have not yet commenced Drawing, but intend to do so. The expense, as nearly as I can determine will not exceed forty dollars. I have been obliged to procure some new text-books but - a much less number than I anticipated. Our lesson in Rhetoric consists of practical exercises given out by Mr. R. and we use no book. If there is any other branch you would
Completed

like to have me persue or any one of these which you think had better be omitted, you will of course tell me. I intended to have asked some advice in my last letter about what branches I should take up but neglected it. I feel lost without some branch of Mathematics. When the classes in Algebra and Geometry recite, it is with difficulty  that I avoid suspending totally my own operations, for the sake of listening. I do love these branches, dearly, but - think I need something else more, at present.

     I hoped to be able to tell you just how my time is employed, but shall not be able, if I send my letter to say, as I wish to do, for my lessons are not all arranged yet.
     I feel anxious to hear from your and know where you are to be and how employed, also of the health of your friends. I think I know something of your emotions when you felt that your sister might be not long for earth. May you be spared that bitterness of grief. The bell for school is ringing and I must go. Yours ever Antoinette.
Completed

Antoinette    Merrimack N.H.
Dec. 24 (1850) 

                                                                                                                                                                       Merrimack  Dec. 18, 1850

My dear friend,

                This is Wednesday afternoon, and though I have one composition to prepare entirely, and another to complete, I believe I cannot deny myself the pleasure of commencing a reply to your kind letter, received this day. I always delight to receive a letter, but thrice welcome they always seem, when I am away from home. But I never attended a school before, where the idea of home seemed so linked with everything. Mr. Russell says he intends this to be, emphatically, a family school. There are about 60 pupils, and I believe more than 50 are members of the family; that is,  they board and room in the Institute building. Some of the rooms are very convenient and pleasant. I had, of course, engaged to be content with one of poorest,  but I prefer this to being deprived of the privilege of being connected with the family of the Principal.
     My room mate is Miss Catherine McKeen.  Her home is in Bradford Vt. where her father is settled as a minister. She has been a teacher recently in Haverhill, N.H. - and left her situation then, in order  to avail herself of Mr. Russell's instruction during the winter. She is a fine scholar. is intelligent

Bangor Dec. 10. 1850
[left-hand side and top] It seems you are busied again both day and evening. I think it would it would be very pleasant to you to be employed this winter so near your friends, particularly as you find your sister still so weak and helpless. We had a box from home yesterday. It contained a number of articles which we had requested to be sent, besides apples and butter. We had a nice time opening it. Father and mother and Jenny are all as well as usual. I do not know but the sight of this epistle will weary you but there came to be a great many things to write about in connection with school affairs. George sends respects. He sits by me, working examples in Greenleaf's Arithmetic. Yours ever, Antoinette.
Completed

and intellectual, and withall, possesses some fine traits of character. I hope to be much benefitted by her society.  We are quite happy together, notwithstanding we have some trials and tribulations.  Nothing very serious however, I would not have you infer but our room is in the North West corner of this edifice, and as cold a place as we could reasonably desire. There are a sufficient quantity of cracks in the floor, and about the windows, to ventilate our rooms most admirably. Sometimes when the wind blows very hard we have considerable trouble to make our fire burn, for the wind takes a freak to carry fire and all, up chimney: Had we known what we should need, we might have brought many things from home which would add to our comfort. We have sent for several articles; among the rest, a pair of tongs, and till they come, our thumb and finger we use for such. I think you would be amused to see us blow the fire, and talk to it, and try in every way to coax it to burn. These little vexations help to keep us in good spirits, - for we can not help being amused. Now, do not think it is always thus - it is only when the wind blows very furiously. 

 Our room is very small indeed, but this does not trouble us much; we are very good natured about it all. Now I am almost sorry I have told you this, for we have so many comforts, and so many advantages that I think we could enjoy nowhere else, that they entirely counterbalance these petty inconveniences.
  O, I do love the very name of school, and I do wish to enjoy
Completed

and improve every moment of my time here. I do not wish a single second to be a blank. The term is but ten weeks, and the third one is flying now - how soon it will all be fled. But I must stop here, for the present, or my compositions will prove failures. The class in Rhetoric have one to prepare every week, in connection with the lesson of Monday. And next Friday evening, I am to read one before the whole company of scholars, visitors, and all - it makes my heart beat quick to think of it.

    Dec. 21}My room mate has gone to Nashua this afternoon, to spend the sabbath with friends there; so I am quite alone, except when brother George comes to see me. Gentlemen are not allowed to visit the ladies' rooms, at all, but Mr. Ray, one of the teachers, gave George permission to come and see me, at any time, not in study hours. So he comes quite often, sometimes to obtain assistance about some lesson, sometimes to bring wood for us, and sometimes just to talk, or to read with me, our letters from home. This adds greatly to our happiness. This afternoon I have prepared a written translation in French, {which our teacher requires of the class every Saturday}. Since finishing that, George and I have been to walk; and now while I am writing, he is getting wood, for our room, and his own.
 This evening (Saturday) we can spend as we choose - it is the only evening of the week that we call our own. Monday evening, at half past seven, is a meeting of the debating society, composed of the Institute scholars; at which we are all required to be present. Tuesday & Friday evenings, we go to
Completed

the lecture room at the same hour, (half past seven) and devote one half hour to the practice of secular music. This is followed by Declamations, Compositions, and the Recitation of Poetry by the ladies. The latter is something new to me. I have not yet attempted it. The ladies take their stand upon the stage, to read compositions, and recite poetry. The exercises of these two evenings are voluntary, but Mr. Russell is very anxious that all should take part in them and most are perfectly willing.  The exercises are, usually, very interesting.

   Wednesday evening, Mr. Russell give a lecture on English Literature, which is followed by what is termed regulated conversation. Some subject is announced beforehand, and all are invited to unite in discussing it, Last Wednesday, each one was requested to describe the scenery about their homes. We had not yet been very sociable on these evenings, but I hope we improve a little, as these weeks pass. Thursday evening we spend half an hour in the practice of sacred music, and then Mr. Russell communicates all the interesting and important items of general intelligence, gathered during the week from newspapers etc. He dwells particularly on what is connected with the progress of Science and Art. Saturday evening we spend in reading or writing to friends. Sabbath evening we have a lecture from the minister of the place (Mr. Little) or from some neighboring minister; or, a biblical lesson. Last Sabbath evening, Mr. Seymour, who was City Missionary at Manchester, lectured , & he is coming again tomorrow eve. He intend to give a series of lectures. on the character and condition of the Indian. He hopes some students will be willing to go and labor among them as missionaries. Perhaps you have heard him speak. I do love to listen to him, notwithstanding all his peculiarities. I think him a truly good man - heartily engaged in the work of doing good.
  The first Sabbath I was here, it stormed, and, as we are two miles from church, and must walk, I did not attend. Mr. Russell met us all in the lecture room, and read a sermon. This, he usually does, when the weather is unpleasant. But this did not make it seem like Sabbath to me. The first two weeks seemed like one long week, without a sabbath. I am quite sure I shall not stay from church when the weather and walking are suitable. It seems strange ti be so far from the meetinghouse. Heard Mr. Little preach last Sabbath, and was much interested in his sermons. He is not a great man. I should not think his education thorough, but his thoughts are good - his manner earnest - and impressive.
    Mr. Russell reads a sermon so well that it is as interesting as to hear many men, preach. Some of the scholars seem to rejoice to have a stormy Sabbath.
Completed

A.P.M. to I.S.M.
Dec. 31. 1850
Merrimack Inst.

                                                                                                                                                Merrimack, Dec.  31 - 1850.

My dear friend,

                It is late, and I am weary, but I wish once more to date 1850. The old year is almost gone - a year full of event - a year long to be remembered. I think of dear Henry to night, and he does not seem far away.  Has he not just begun to live? Miss McKeen, my room mate, buried her only brother last June. We feel that we can share each others' sorrows, & that we can rejoice together too. Those dear lost ones are not sad tonight, and we should not be sad for them, though it seems, sometimes hard to "live without their vanished light." O how little we dreamed, one year ago this night, what the year was bringing for us. One only knows what the hours and moments of the year now coming will bring, - but it is very sweet to confide all to Him.
Jan. 1. 1851. The morning of the new year has come - bright - and beautiful - May it be to thee a happy one.
  The new -year's wish has echoed, merrily, through the halls of our building this morning, and has followed many a tap at our door. I could not help wishing, silently, that all these hearts, now so light and happy, might know the true source of all real joy.
 But I must not stop this morning to write much. I have

[left-hand side and top] Brother George will return next term. This term has three weeks after this, and one week only of vacation succeeds. The rooms in the building are fast being engaged. I have as yet received no instructions from my several guardians and counsellors, as to whether I shall secure, a room for the coming term. It will be soon be too late to do so, if I should wish. Mr. Ray thinks the entire building will be occupied by ladies next term. The applications are greater than at any given time. I will direct to Milo, since you were there when you wrote. I love to have a letter. The first half of the days that intervene, I think of the one just received, and the last half of the one I hope is coming. O I meant to tell you how many letters I wrote last year - 61 and I received 59. More than usual I think. Very truly yours, Antoinette.
Completed

written a few lines home too, just enough to let all know that I remember them, I am a little more in haste, with my lessons than usual this morning - for Miss  McKeen is sick and I have been trying my skill to releive her and she really says she feels better. Is'nt that good? It is painful to have friends sick, but it is joy to comfort them when suffering, and to hear the words "I am better now."
Jab. 12 - I had decided not to send this. it was written so long ago, but since recieving yours, I thought I would send it  - just as it is - I think you will excuse its antiquity.

   The information your letter contained, come somewhat suddenly upon me. I was not expecting it so speedily. You too have a dear brother, for an angel guard above. It is indeed sad to think that so much of youth and promise, should pass away from earth, but it is delightful to reflect that it blooms in fresh beauty, and with greater loneliness, in Heaven. "This corruptible immortality," How full of precious truth is the fifteenth of 1 Cor. I need not tell you that my warmest sympathies are with you. I rejoice with you in that perfect triumph over the last of foes. Death does not seem the "King of Terrors," when he comes in so beautiful a form. Our precious Savior will comfort you all. Well may they mourn who have lost friends without a Savior; but we may rather rejoice, that the good may die.
  Six persons are, to day, to be admitted to the church
Completed

in Dunbarton. All young people, and five are members of the same family - it is a happy day to my dear Father, and to all good people. I have enjoyed the Sabbath exceedingly. I listened to a most impressive sermon, in the forenoon, from Galatians 6- 14. This afternoon, in connection with the administration of the Lord's supper, two person were admitted to the church, one of whom was baptized. Since returning from church, one of whom was baptised. Since returning from church, we have had an interesting prayer meeting. This female prayer meeting was commenced the first of the term, with but three or four attendants - this eve. the little room was crowded. I cam but think it has already done good. Deep feeling was manifest - today - tears plowed from almost every eye. One young lady expressed a determination to ask Christ, and said she sometimes dared to hope she was a Christian. There are very few professors here - ? has a weight of responsibility - rests upon those few,  with regard to their companions. Prayer will avail much. We cannot value it too highly, or be too often engaged in that which unlocks all heaven's treasures. & brings every blessing from above.

  I believe I mentioned in some letter, that we walk two miles to meeting. When the days is as pleasant as this has been, it is a most delightful walk, the road is very level, and tall, dark, pines rise on each side, almost the whole distance. To day the sky was of that clear deep blue, so glorious to behold, the air pure, and even the dear little birds
Completed

were singing. we could not help stopping to listen to them.. The Institute Scholars, threading their way, two and two, through the light and shade under the trees, formed rather an interesting scene.  I do not know as I have told you that we are almost entirely surrounded by evergreen forests, which not only help to keep us warm, but are very beautiful . In some spots where the brown and withered leaves of the oak are interspersed, they seem to have almost the beauty of the Autumn woods.
Jan. 13. I rose at five this morning have had a nice walk, and have finished copying my composition, to hand Mr. Russell this morning, and now I can write a letter with a light heart duty before pleasure, you know is the maxim.  I have plenty of compositions to write.  Our Rhetoric scholars bring in one every Monday morning, the French class prepares one every other Saturday and occasionally one must be prepared for the exercises of Tuesday & Friday evening.  In addition to this, for the last two weeks, the class in Retoric have prepared one nearly every day.  So my mind has been quite closely occupied.  Wherever I go and whatever I do, I am thinking continually of composition.  I think it has been very profitable to me, though it is somewhat, wearisome.  I suppose we shall have a little change in our exercises this week, which will be very agreeable.  I have read two compositions, on the stage, and sung twice.  Is not that considerable for little Nettie to do ?  We have quite a company of visitors, on Tuesday and Friday evenings. Last Friday, a large company came from Manchester.  We have frequent visits from friends of education.  Since I wrote, prof. Samuel Willow, an elocutionist, has been here.  Dr. T.S. Lambert has been here, and delivered six very interesting lectures on Physiology.  He is from New York city but is lecturing in Boston this winter.  
I feel much happier than at first, for I am now acquainted with the scholars and feel interested in them.  I enjoy the society of my room mate more and more every day.  
The weather is warmer now, and our room is very comfortable besides we have substitute for a carpet on the floor and have nailed a shawl over one window.  so we keep quite warm
Brother George has been sick for three days.  We took a severe cold and was very feverish.  I felt very anxious about him, the first two days, but the load is somewhat lightened to day for he is much better, though not yet quite able to go down to the school room.  He seems quite interested in study.
Completed

Merrimack Normal Institute, Feb. 6, 1851
My dear friend, 
More than three weeks since, did I dispatch a letter in reply to yours received Jam. 8, and never  a word have I received in return, though I have listened most intently, and questioned the East Wind of it burden;  You must be, methinks, as weary way off that your answer should be so long in journeying.  But seriously now, I have so much confidence in your punctuality, and regard for the happiness of this same little self, and possessing, as I hope, somewhat of the "Chasity that thinketh no evil, I feel some that you must have written, and your letter, by some accident of Post Office, have failed to reach me. so, I will write again to ask of you a substitute for the missing letter, for I confess that I am not over patient in sustaining such losses.  We are on the verge of a closing time, tomorrow is our last great day.  There is to be public examination continuing all day, and rhetorical exercises are to occupy the evening, so I must be very busy studying to day.  I have part in a dialogue for the evening, and some music to practise, so I must deny myself the pleasure of writing
Completed

more than a mere note this morning.  I have not yet learned from my dear advisers, three. whether it is deemed expedient for me to continue another term at the "institute."  I only know that I go home on Saturday and that whatever they do counsel, will be cheerfully complied with.  I do not now how I could live without somebody to tell me always what to do .  The expenses of this term for board, tuition & books have been a little less that  $29.00 .Not as much as I expected.  I was not able to attend to drawing, because the teacher in that branch has been sick all the term so that I have ample means to stay another term, if it is thought advisable. My term has passed very pleasantly and profitably, although I regret, as usual, that I have not made much more progress.  We are to have but one week of vacation. I spoke to Mr. Ray, who has charge of the boarding, to reserve a room until I should know if I returned. This was some time since, but I still think there will be rooms, because preference is given to those who have previously attended.  I can hardly realize that ten weeks are so nearly expired, and that, nothing occurring to prevent, George and I will be at home day after tomorrow I have heard frequently from home; our good Dunbarton people are to make their pastor a pastoral visit next Wednesday (Feb 12) and I am commissioned by my mother to invite most cordially your own self to be present.  Nettie would be glad to run and carry the message and say for herself "Please, do come" but where should she go?  I feel somewhat in doubt, as to where.
Completed

this letter may find you, but I do hope you are well and happy, wherever it may be. I know that whatever may be your circumstances of pleasure, there is an aching sense of something gone from earth, and thoughts of the brother departed, will come like the still, mournful rain, but when the Sun of Righteousness shines through, the bright rainbow of promise makes your spirit glad again. O how sweet and consoling are the precious words of promise in God's book - how full and rich they are. You certainly have my tenderest sympathy, and sympathy it may be, since I have felt the same sorrow, and, I hope, the same consolation.

   But I am writing a letter after all, and stealing time from my lessons, and as they have little more to ask, I think they must be heeded. I am fearful the invitation will reach you too late. I should have sent it before, but I waited to hear from you. However this may be, I hope we may see you soon, if you are not so busily occupied that it is impossible. We shall look for you a little next week. I do not know how long it may take this letter to reach you. I need not ask you to write, if you do so come - for you have, I believe, a heart to feel for all human troubles, and, among the rest, for the letter starvation of your
                                                                                                                      Antoinette

I think I will direct to Bangor, and to the care of your brother - there, since I am not sure that you are there.
Completed

Home, Feb. 15. 1851.

My dear friend,

             I cannot tell you how very anxious I feel, to hear some tidings from you. I have heard nothing, since Jan. 4, and a long, long time it had seemed to me. This will be the third letter I have written to you, since then. When I wrote last, I supposed you must have mailed a reply to the first, and that, by some accident, it had been lost. Now, I hardly know what to suppose. I sometimes am fearful that you are sick, and unable to write, or even to dictate to another. The wintry winds, and chilling frosts, perhaps, have proved to severe for endurance. Is it so? If thus, it may be that you are among dear friends, who will kindly watch over you, and "soften all your care." Did I only know that you live, and are in health. Your last letter has been read, and read again, I know not how many times.
   I returned to Dunbarton, at the close of the term at ? {Feb. 8} and have been at home since - happy as usual except that I have felt so much anxiety
Completed

to hear from you. I will tell you, frankly, that this has troubled me. Unaccountable and mysterious it seems. Still, I can but feel that it may be like one of those dark clouds, with the shining edge, which is so very bright on the other side. Thus I hope it may prove.

      I would write more, were I sure this would reach you. If it does, please let me know if you have written to me, or have received letters from me, since Jan. 4. Of course, I am very impatient to hear from you. I can hardly endure this suspense. O! if you are only well! But I must try to be patient.
                                                                                                                                   Your Antoinette.
Completed

Home, March 5, 1851-
My dear friend,-
                              Your kind letter went first to Reed's Ferry, and having been remailed, by my brother, reaches me here last night, bringing joy to my heart. I was altogether too happy to write, last evening, but - I must hasten to day to reply, and send to you a free and full pardon, for I greatly fear that my last letter, if you have received it, has troubled you in turn. I believe it was somewhat mournful for I usually write as I feel. Now please, light a fire with that, will you not? For I do not love to think of its existence. I write now, with totally different feelings. Then I thought of you as sick, or enduring some species of evil - now, I rejoice that, instead of this, you were well, and enjoying so highly your forest journeyings - reading from Nature's great book, and feasting "on raptures ever new." You need not fear that your description was uninteresting or wearisome. Not so - indeed, for it quite delighted me. I have pictured, in my mind, a most enchanting scene of life in the woods, which I shall always love to look upon. I wonder not that you enjoyed it much for the time. The "lumber men's lamps" brought to my mind, some of the shanties of the West, which are constructed in a very similar manner.
   I presume it will prove to be all for the best that I did

[left-hand side] Perhaps I ought to mention that this principal reason why I am not now at Merrimack is that I did not like to engage a room, without being sure that I should occupy it, since  in so doing, I should deprive some one else of that privilege of attending. The rooms were all engaged, for this term, before the close of the Winter session, and some applicants were turned away, besides.
Completed

not return to Merrimack, for brother George writes that Mr. Russell has not been in school but three days this term, and those the three first. This would have sadly disturbed my recitations had I been there. His health is very comfortable during the warm weather, but he suffers much during the Winter months, and the early portion of Spring. Besides Mr. Russell's illness, I could have had no advantages in Drawing, for tho the daughter of Mr. R., who instructs in this branch, is sick also  - has been out of health for a long time. I have decided, with my parents advice, to go over to Concord, in a few days, and spend perhaps three weeks there, in a very excellent family; that of Mrs. French, the widow of a missionary to Sian. I shall have the advantage of good society, some time for reading, and shall receive instruction in Drawing and Painting. I think I may spend the time profitably and pleasantly.

  When I came home, I felt exceedingly desirous to return to the Institute, particularly on account of the advantages there afforded for pursuing the study of History, and also of Elocution. but Mr. Russell's illness would have prevented my receiving the anticipated benefit. He was to have charge of the students in History, this term. His information on this subject is very extensive indeed.
   Our examination passed very pleasantly, though we were all sufficiently fatigued at its close. We had a good number of visitors during the day ti listen to the review of the studies, among them the Rev. Mr. Years, - the Mass. Com. School Commissioner who addressed the students, in the forenoon, is quite an
Completed

manner, on the subject of Education. The exercises of the day were interspersed with the reading of Compositions. We went upon the stage to read them, as usual, mine came in the last of the afternoon, thus giving me a long while to dread it. You would not be likely to imagine what was my subject - it was "The pursuit of gardening is production of good." I had not intended it for that occasion, but not having sufficient time to finish, to my mind, what I had designed, I made use of a substitute.  In the evening, our Lecture Room, was filled to overflowing, and the exercise consisted of recitations, declamations, and dialogues, many of which were original. There was but a single composition read, in the evening. There was a French dialogue, in which all the scholars in French took part - this was quite amusing. We sung twice - at the close an original hymn appropriate to the time, composed by Miss McKeen, my room mate.

   Father did not go to M. to witness the closing exercises. But he met us at Goffstown the next day. It was extremely cold, but we did not suffer. George was obliged to get out and run a number of times in order to keep himself comfortable.
  On Wednesday, of vacation week, the day of the Visit, we greeted 120 of the parishioners - more than one eighth of the whole population of our town. They seemed a very happy company. We had an address to the young people, from one of their number - it was original, and very good. As usual, there was considerable singing and instrumental music. Mr. John Parker was here, Mr. Raymond, with his wife and sister Mary. Twenty young men made a very beautiful present, to my mother, of a China Tea Set. The names of the donors
Completed

were handed in, in the course of the evening.

  I believe I have not mentioned to you, that Mr. Harris Ryder, was married, on Thanksgiving morning, to Miss Elisabeth Kimball. You doubtless, recollect them both.
  I have been very busy since I came home, much of the time is writing for father. He is preparing for the press a work on "Analysis of the English Language." I have been copying. He has also as Chairman of the School Committee of this town been writing a report of the schools to be printed. This I copied, also - request for me to go to Carlyle, in that state, and take charge of a Select School, and, a few days previous to this, while at the Institute, the teacher of the Academy at Westminster, Vt. offered me a situation as assistant there. I tried to find some one to take the place at Carlyle, but could not succeed. No one to whom I mentioned it wished to go so far from home. Miss Webster a widow lady - a friend of my mother, is now erecting a building at her own expense, at Carlyle, to be used as a school room. She was pioneer teacher at the West, previous to her marriage, and, since the death of her husband, has resumed the employment. She wishes now, to resign the school to the care of another, only reserving for herself the supervise of some of the primary classes. She had accomplished much good there.
    During the vacation, my brother George was examined for admission to the church. He will unite at the next communion, and probably two or three others with him. O! how much these young disciples need the prayers of God's people. May they "endure to the end," and accomplish very great good in the world. George. in his last letter, told us that a few young men in the Institute, had established a Sabbath evening prayer meeting which they enjoyed very much.
  Is your sister fully recovered, and are other friends well?    
  My parents send much love. Please direct to Dunbarton, as my father will send my letters to me, while I am at Concord. 
  Have you satisfactory employment in prospect for the coming Season? 
  My best wishes ever, for your success.                        
                                                                                     Most truly yours.
                                                                                                      Antoinette.
Completed

Concord, March 18, 1851
My dear friend,
Quietly seated, I am, this evening, in the comfortable sitting room of the friend whom I mentioned to you when I last wrote, (Mrs. French).  It has been snowing and blowing most furiously all day long.  I take my lessons in Painting about half a mile distant from here. It was quite a tax upon my strength to keep myself and umbrella upright in my walks, to and fro. My dinner was very kindly sent to me, thus saving me one journey. I have taken four lessons in a day, occupying the time from nine till twelve and from one till four.  The time in the mornings, and the evenings, with one or two exceptions, I have spent in reading and talking.  Mrs. French and her mother and sister, who live in the same house, are all valuable friends.  I prize their society very highly and I need not add that I have enjoyed, exceedingly my stay with them.  I have been reading a most interesting book, written by Mrs. S. Nicholson.  It is "Ireland's Welcome to a Stranger".  The authoress went to Ireland for the purpose of learning the true condition of the poor there, She went about from one lowly dwelling to another, and the book tells of the 

[written on the side}
One thing I had forgotten to ask. Did you receive a sermon of Father's on the "Fugitive Slave Law"? I wonder if this is causing as much excitement in Maine as, here.  It is the general theme of conversation here. Mr. Bouton, of the North Church in Concord wrote a sermon in defense of the law.  Some of his best people are exceedingly dissatisfied with him on this account.
Completed

reception she met, and the state in which she found the dwellers. They are indeed down trodden and oppressed.  May their day of deliverance speedily come.  I really feel interested in poor Ireland.  I have also been learning more than I ever knew before of the Canada Mission.  O! how many ways there are in which to be useful.  Day before yesterday I went, with Mrs. French, to visit a lady in the village, in company with Rev. Mr Ransom and wife, who are now living in Bennington N.Y. but were formerly Missionaries on Western ground.  I enjoyed the time there spent very much.  Mrs. Ransom is an excellent woman, constantly endeavoring to do good.  And then the family we were visiting, it is indeed a model family.  There are three of the sweetest children I ever saw decidedly. You would enjoy spending a half day there, to witness the love, order, and obedience which reign so perfectly.  Happy parents, happy children.  Each face, silently, but impressively, told me of the quiet joy within.  Since making this visit, I have attended the "Ladies" Missionary Meeting".  They commence with Scripture reading, and prayer, and occupy the time afterwards in sewing, while some one of the members reads interesting Missionary Intelligence.  These are some of the very best of people in the place.

  Last evening I spent very happily with Mrs. French.  She has a great variety of curious articles which she brought home from Siam, when she left the Mission Station there.  She exhibited them,
Completed

and explained their use to me.  O! I wish I could remember half she told me.  I have thought it over once, and shall endeavor thus to do , many times, that I may retain as much as possible.  
I was very happy to receive your letter, dated March 8.  Probably, you received one from me, very soon after writing it.  Yours did not come to me quite as soon as if I had been at home, but father sent it as soon as he could. I hope you will find employment precisely to your mind.  I know you must feel unpleasantly to be in suspense so long.  I should like much to see the "Big pile of wood" and the "Wood Chopper" too.  I venture to think I should know him.  I feel as though I too, ought to be working harder, not that I am not busy now, but do you not think I had better be "school ma'am" one summer more, forgive me for asking, after you have told me you thought it not best, but I did not know but you might think differently.  I seems "all for the best" that I did not return to Reeds Ferry, for Mr. Russell had not been in school except the first three days of the term & is now away, journeying, in quest of health.  You may prefer to have me return there for the summer term, should Mr. R. resume his place, as it is hoped he will then be able to do.  I have funds sufficient, and will so do , if you advise.  George came home last Saturday on account of Mr. R's sickness. will go back the summer term.  At least, this is his intention  Father and mother feel anxious to have
Completed

George and I visiting our relatives in Westboro' Mass., now that he has a few weeks leisure.  It is possible we may, after two or three weeks.  I shall go home, from Concord, one week from next Saturday (March 29). 
Spring is really here once more.  The winter has fled so rapidly that I can hardly realize that we have had one  The robins have come back to us. dear little creatures.  I heard them merrily singing a few days since.  Who would not welcome the dear singers back again.  The singing of birds never sounds sweeter than in the early spring.  I do not know though it must have been very sweet to listen to them in winter, about the lumber men's camps, as you did.  How I did enjoy that account.  If you have any more stories of forest life, I shall be most happy to hear about them.
March 22, I thought this sheet would have been on it's way to Maine this, but my evenings have been so occupied with meetings and company that I have neglected it.  
Father came in to see me two days since.  I shall go home in one  week from this day.  Father said three of the school agents had been in since town meeting to know if I would teach this summer, so I'll have no trouble to find a place.

I am going this morning to visit the "Natural History Rooms". How happy I should be, were you here to go also.  There is quite a flourishing Natural History Society here. They have had lectures every week during the Winter, they are finished now.

But I must stop or Miss Allison will be waiting for me. she is going out with me.  And beside it will be time for my Drawing, before a great while.
In haste but truly as ever, Antoinette.
Completed

Apr. 20 '51
A.B.P. to I.S.M.                                                                                                                                      Home, April 20 1851.
Dunbarton.

                             My dear friend,-
                                      The labors of the day are completed, I believe, and, with great pleasure, I commence answering your kind letter, received yesterday. I have been baking and ironing and sewing, and doing a little of almost every thing, during the day, and this evening, for an hour. I have read aloud to my father and mother, as is my practise generally, though father does not always leave his study to listen. It is raining very fast to night = we have had considerable rain during the month, and it has improved the grass and trees wonderfully. The season seems quite early with us - very much in advance of last year. We have had flowers for six weeks. A vase of hay-flowers is by my side while I write, filling the air with perfume and looking so cheerful - the dear little creatures - how I do love them. I think I'll separate one little darling from the group, and send it to you, with one or two others I have just been pressing. They have all grown this very Spring.
          I was quite as much surprised to observe the 

[left-hand side] Father and Mother send much love. A.
Completed

Milo post=mark on your last letter, as I was on seeing New-York, upon the preceeding one. You have journeyed considerably during the few weeks past, and I think you have enjoyed it much, notwithstanding the unpleasantness of being so long chiefly among strangers. I recollect very distinctly many of the cities and towns through which you passed in N.Y.  It seemed pleasant to me, to hear their names again. I was much interested in the account of your Sabbath in N.Y. It was an exceedingly unpleasant day, here. I thought of you, but did not suspect, of course, that you were listening to Dr. Spring, or Dr. Cheever. I heard two excellent sermons, on that day, preached by Mr. Manshall from 2nd., whose name I believe I have before mentioned in some letter. He was here some weeks last Summer. We expect he will be here next sabbath, when three individuals are to be admitted to the church, - one of them my brother.  He wishes now, to become a Minister of the Gospel. How much he needs our prayers. May I ask you to remember him? He seems now fully decided with regard to his future course. O may he be very useful, and "endure to the end." He returns to Merrimack, in a little more than two weeks.
Completed

Brother G. and I think of occupying the time that remains before his term commences, in visiting some relatives in Boston and Westboro,  Mass. This is mother's plan, and she is quite anxious to have it accomplished. If we go, we shall leave home next Monday, and be away, perhaps, a little more than two weeks. After that, mother says she believes she shall claim me, as long as Dunbarton is my home. It will give me great pleasure to comply with her wishes, not only for the sake of gratfying her, but because nowhere have I ever been so happy as at home. I am hoping to find some time for mental culture, and any advice from you, with regard ti the best method of spending this time, I should be most happy to follow. I believe I need as much as anything, to take lessons in talking. There is nothing of which I oftener feel the need than the power of easy and ready expression in conversation. Tupper tells the truth about it: - "For at every turn to want a word, - thou canst not guess that want; It is as lack of breath on bread : life hath no grief more galling." I think I shall adopt the plan of reading a passage from some work every day, for the express purpose of reproducing it in my own words, with mother and Jenny for my audience. But
Completed

I am occupying considerable space with the story of mt planning for the future.
Aug. 1} This is the morning of May day. It is rainy - but - the sun seems half shining, and I am thinking the clouds will all fly away before noon. The birds are singing very sweetly, as they do every morning. We usually open the doors for a time to hear their music more plainly. We need no caged birds to sing to us - for we have the "merriest trills" of the happy, free songsters.

            I have been tracing out on the map, the various railroads you have mentioned. I should think it would puzzle you to recollect the names of so many, and yet they seem to be constantly multiplying. You ask if I should not prefer to be in New England. I should indeed. I hope you will be able to obtain the situation on the Hartford and Fishkill road, which you think would suit you so well.  Perhaps this delay, which seems so unpleasant, will secure you the very place you will like best. I do hope you will not be low-spirited, and I think you cannot be very low, for I imagine you are one of those who "carrieth his sunshine with him."  You say you do not wish to get upon another such road at the N.H. Central. Now let me whisper in your ear, that I feel quite happy that you were once located thereon.
     I think I was at Concord when I last wrote. I painted three pictures while there - two were quite large. Two were landscapes and the others a representation of a little boy "tired of play"- I enjoyed my stay at C. very much. I think it was a benefit in many respects.
     Father saw Mr. Tilley a short time since. He has much to encourage him among his people - a number are to unite with the church there next Sabbath. And there still continues to be a great deal of interest.
     Is there preaching still at Milo?   
     I am glad your dear sister seems to be gaining at all. The spring weather is said not to be very good for those in feeble health. It seems to affect Mother somewhat, but I think she will be well as usual, when Summer comes.
   I need not say I should have been happy to see you at D. But I do not much wonder that you did not come, for I think Dunbarton may be as difficult of access as was the place you mention where you found your relatives in N.Y., and I do not know as there is any prospect of anything better. It would be very pleasant to enjoy your society for a number of days, or as long as you could stay, now that you are out of employ. This is a fine place to study. But I must stop. From your own 
                                         Antoinette.
Completed

Dunbarton June 19, 1851.

My dearest friend,-            

                                    To'night your kind letter, dated at Chicago, reached me. I cannot tell you how rejoiced I was to hear from you, or how much I thank you for writing. I thought I would give myself the pleasure of sitting down directly to begin a letter, for it is a "perfect comfort" to write to you. In Illinois! You have found the prairie-land - but how far away! A feeling of loneliness comes over me when I think how many miles are between us. When shall I ever see you? It does seem as though I could not relinquish this pleasure which I have been hoping to enjoy. For two very long weeks I have watched every day. When the door bell rung my first thought was of you, and I have opened the door, almost expecting to greet you, but now I do not know but I shall despair. I do truly feel disappointed. But I must not write thus, for I believe you will go just where duty seems calling.
   I hope you will find just such a situation

[top, upside down] Sabbath Eve. July 20 I think I will send this letter by Mr. Wallace to be mailed at Manchester tomorrow - it may reach you a little more seasonably. It could not go from here till Tuesday afternoon. You will see, by the dates, that this sheet is somewhat ancient but I think I'll send it notwithstanding. I hope you have not been sad any to day, though probably you could not attend meeting. I have been watching the Western clouds, and thinking of my dear friend, away towards the setting sun. I wish I could do something to make you happy to night. Well, this letter is surely long enough. I only wish it were better. Write please as often as you can with your many duties, and tell me your pleasures, and plans, and troubles too.
Do not forget that I have not written for a long while, and pardon the length of this.
From your own, Antoinette.
Completed

as you wish. May the God who holds worlds in his hand, and yet takes care of every little flower, watch over you everywhere, and guide your pathway always.

    How long you are obliged to wait for letters. I sympathize with you truly. You must be exceedingly anxious to have some tidings from Maine - particularly from our dear sister. Is she in Bangor now, or at Milo?
     Perhaps you are at Springfield by this time. I passe through many of the places you mention when going west, and at precisely the same season of the year's commenced the journey the first week in June from Albany, westward.

You must enjoy journeying now, I think, in this sweetest of months- beautiful June.

 Everything is delightful here. It seems like "a new and perfect world," fresh and bright, and oh so fair. I sometimes almost forget that I have anything to do but listen to bird music - look at the grass and trees and flowers, watch the shadows, and from the loveliness that is everywhere around, "take in my priceless portion." But you are looking at nature's scenes, quite as enchantingly fair, though differently characterised. In going to
Completed

Springfield I presume you will pass directly through Lockport, where I attended church and spent much time. I used to think it a beautiful place then, but it is probably much improved now. The canal passing through was finished only a few weeks before I came home. But it is quite late, and I am sitting here all alone while I have written, and I suppose I ought to stop.

June 26.} To day I returned with my father from the village of Loudon Mills, where we went to attend the "Conference of Churches." The meetings were very interesting indeed. I never enjoyed any more. I do hope the impression will remain, and make me a great deal better; but I don't know; I sometimes feel totally discouraged. How we need to be constantly heeding the injunction, "Watch and pray", I surely have not a single doubt of the truth of the Bible description of the natural heart, "deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked." Resolutions, very many I make, but, oh, so little real progress. How happy these must be, who, bearing the Christian name, can work for Jesus, not alone for duty's sake, but because the "Love of Christ constrains them."
Completed

I had a fine ride to Loudon. We had delightful weather and a great many ministers were present, making the meetings rather more than usually interesting.
Since I came home, I have called to see some sick neighbors, - two ladies, one of whom has been sick for a long time. I carried some strawberries. We are just beginning to have them in abundance - hope you have as many as you wish. I should love dearly to give you some of ours.

   I believe I have not told you anything of the last journey. I enjoyed it finely. We had pleasant days during the whole two weeks we were away, and the warmest of welcomes from dear friends, not one of whom failed to make inquiries for yourself - all were very anxious to see you. Spent several days in Boston and left there, for home, just one week before the day you journeyed from Bangor to Boston, on the way to N. York. While there we visited Mount Auburn. Have you ever been there?

It is truly a lovely spot. One loves to linger there. If all those sleeping ones might rise to live and reign in Heaven, no sad thoughts of the day when the trumpet shall sound would mingle with the pleasure of a visit - to this "garden of graves." I brought away some little acorns, as a relic.

   --I have commenced reading a ponderous volume of Stephen's Travels. I have so many interruptions that I know not when I shall arrive at the end - but - I mean to persevere. You have taught me a lesson of perseverance. It must have been exceedingly discouraging to find place after place, either already occupied, or, not ready. Onward, still onward, till you were away in Illinois, and how much farther ere this, I know not . I venture to hope no farther. this seems a long distance, but I do love the very name of Illinois. It is connected with some of the dearest remembrances of my life, 

[upside down] Antoinette  Dunbarton N.H.   June 20, 1851

                                                                    Aug. 2 __

Antoinette Dunbarton N.H.
July 19, 1851
Mt. Hopkins Aug. 2 1851
This perhaps makes it purer. I never saw whiskey used as you mention, or any ardent spirits. Horrible, is it not, to be taught from very childhood, to love the drunkards beverage! Your decision may have a good influence. I tried hard to learn to drink coffee, but did not succeed. Do you have a Well, or only a substitute for one? I was just wondering too, whether you drink a "glass of water," for I used to drink from saucers, cups, bowls, pitchers etc.

  The rest of the family are just at supper now  { I do not go without mine, by the way, - I only ate it quick} Perhaps you are eating in that airy room with two open ends. I think that must be a good, cool place some of these warm days. If I knew how the house stands, and the direction of the barn from it,  I should have the whole picture in my mind. Does it stand on the open prairie or near to the timber?
 You have a Work Bench for your table - my trunk was mine. I used to write, kneeling before it sometimes. But oftener I sat upon it
Completed

July 19  I sit down joyfully to write, for I am very very happy that you can have some letters yourself now. Yours reached me a few minutes since. I have read it - twice, and have looked on the Map to trace your journey, and see where you are. I need not tell you I am overjoyed to hear from you. I feel almost as if I had journeyed westward, traversed the prairie, and re-visited log-cabins. I am glad you are in no worse a condition. A comfortable barn, or indeed a barn of any description, was, four years ago one of the extras of western country life, and in the settlements where I spent a year, there was but our double-log house. So I am looking at the sunny side of the picture, and feeling very thankful that you have found so good a shelter. But how I do want to send you some of our good, pure, cold water. I know how to sympathise, truly. I sued to drink as seldom and as rapidly as possible, for it seemed unendurable. Some put Indian Meal in the water, and let it settle before drinking
[left-hand side and top] whose house is in Landaff, this state, within a few miles of Franconia, has been to visit me this summer. She was here this June. Another who resides in Barnstead N.Y. I am expecting every day. When thinking of dear friends away, I can but remember God's happy home where Christians will meet to be always together. Your letter from Springfield came in due season and was gladly received as always. Mother sends love and Father would were he at home. I am glad that you are decided not to remain if the climate prove not favorable to health. I do hope the fever & ague will keep far away - and everything else that is naughty.

 You have a Work Bench for your table - my trunk was mine. I used to write, kneeling before it sometimes. But oftener I sat upon it

holding a little portable desk, on which I wrote. Your letter quite brings back to me prairie life in all its wildness. Notwithstanding the frequent inconveniences, there is much to enjoy: and we learn that happiness consists not alone in the elegancies, or even the comforts of life.

    Now I'll leave the West for a little while, and tell you something of what is transpiring in this small corner of the world. Father has gone to Manchester to preach tomorrow, and Mr. Wallace, good man, to be with us. Father is in usual heath. My mother has for four or five weeks, been unusually ill; but she has seemed gradually gaining during the present week. Sister Jenny is well, and attending school.
  A cousin, nine years old, came home with me from Westboro' Mass. Her name is Harriet Brigham. She is the daughter of one of my mother's brothers. She also attends school. I find myself quite busily employed in caring for our little family and attending to company, of which we have more than usual. I am enjoying the summer very much - have been at home but one summer

[left-hand side] Mother says she is very glad that though you are so far away from your friends, you have the ability to commune with Nature and with God, and are disposed to do so.
Completed

before, for a number of years.

  Brother George is at University still, but the term closes next week, and he will be home for some weeks. Father thinks of sending him to "Union Academy" at Plainfield N.H. in the Autumn. He selects this place on account of the advantages for pursuing Classic Studies, and in order to avail himself of the Fund of that Institution, for the benefit of students who need; which will very much reduce the expense.
  George was at home two or three days the first of the month. Came home the third of July and remained until the fifth, when we went to Henniker to a Celebration, which but for rain, would have been attended on the fourth. The Manchester and Goffstown Sabbath Schools went. About 4000 people were present, and the Addresses were said to be fine. The clergymen from the several towns were the speakers. Instead of going to Celebration I went to ride with father, in the afternoon. Jenny and Hattie went also. Poor, dear mother was left at home, because she did not feel able to go. She is better now. She has been to ride almost every day for two weeks and it is very beneficial. It rained tremendously, almost all day on the 4th, but we were unusually happy at home.
     I went to Mr. Raymond's a few days since, to carry to the cars two ladies who had been visiting here. - stopped for supper with Mrs. William Raymond. The family are all well, except Mary. I do not know whether or not tour are acquainted with her. She has been unwell for some time, and it is feared she will not recover. She is inclined to consumption. I love to go to see Mrs. Raymond. I feel more acquainted with her than with almost anyone in our own town.
  All my most intimate friends seem to be at a distance, and I keep the acquaintance almost entirely by writing. One of my very dear school mates, Emily Peavy,
Completed

Antoinette Dunbarton N.H.
Aug. 17. 1851
Mt. Hawkins Ill, Sept. 13

                                                                                                            Dunbarton, Aug. 17, / 51
    I welcomed your kind letter, my dear friend, yesterday afternoon - very gladly, I assure you. In the evening I sat down and attempted to write something in reply; but found myself so tired that the idea was soon relinquished. I could not pick up a single thought that was in any way possible. We have had constant company for more than two weeks, and more than usual all summer. I enjoy this very much; but at times feel somewhat wearied. I never had so many cares, as a housekeeper, before, - perhaps it is just what I need. And, I do not know how it happens, but I believe that notwithstanding all these domestic duties, I have found more time than ever before, when at home, for reading. Two ladies are visiting here now, and, since they have been here, {nearly two weeks, one of them} we have read considerable aloud every day. To night - I have been reading

[left-hand side] Is Mr. Roots one of your company of Engineers? Is he an Eastern man?
Completed

what Tupper says on Death. I have read it many times before, but it always seemed new, and always more full of thought.

 I have attended church all day, and sabbath school at noon. Probably you have been unable to find a meeting. But the heart may be a sanctuary - pure and holy, where God as truly dwells and smiles, as in the midst of the great congregation. But it really is a very great privation to be unable to meet God, and worship him, in his earthly temple, with those who bear his image. When this cannot be how pleasant to know that we may find God everywhere. It seems to me difficult - to feel as if it was truly the Sabbath and to require great watchfulness to be entirely in a sabbath day mood when one cannot go to meeting. It seems like one long week, without the change and rest the sabbath gives, when employed in the usual way.
  Monday } To day I have been washing, and cooking, and, this afternoon, mending for my father, and reading a very little - just enough to say I have caught a new idea. Some writer says we should always do as much as this, ere we sleep. I deem it a very good rule.
Completed

I cannot avoid feeling some anxious lest your health should be injured by Illinois climate. I am sorry you have been sick and very glad you seem so far to have regained health & strength, and I shall try to imagine you well and strong. Do not work hard till you are fully well. Father and mother feel, as I supposed they would, some solicitude about the effect of the climate- more so, I presume, than if I had not once been there; and found it, in the northern part, unfavorable to health. Still I think, and they do, that I might have been well in time; and that perhaps disease was induced by too great labor, and too many cares, and not sufficient efforts to preserve health. I should perhaps know better how to do, were I to go, again. If there seems a probability that you will remain there, and that you will, as you mention, before a great while wish somebody to be there with you, you would without doubt, like to tell Antoinette how you are planning to live, that she may know better, what to do, to be ready.

 For myself it matters not much where I am, provided that "true warm heart" is near for me to trust in. Were I sad a moment, it would be for my dear parents. For them, I should love
Completed

to be nearer New England. But they will be content with what Providence appoints. The climate is the chief objection, in their view.

  What has occurred with regard to your pay must be exceedingly gratifying to you, not so much for the additional profit, as for the good will and confidence so decidedly manifested. I enjoy this with you. It is a delightful feeling to be conscious of gaining friends though in a strange land.
  Two weeks of brother George's vacation are gone. I went to Merrimack, to attend the examination at the close of last term and enjoyed it much, met many of my former school-mates there. I may have mentioned in a previous letter, that George is going to Meriden Academy. He expects to be admitted as a beneficiary there. We feel very glad of this, for now he can study without embarrasment. Father thinks he will stay three years if his health should be good. He has nearly decided not to send him to College, but to have him pursue an independent course, that he may avoid spending time with branches which will be nearly or quite useless to him. What think you of this plan? I cannot tell you how much I enjoy his being at home, but the pleasure will soon be past. He goes the thirteenth  of this month.
   George has procured some dumb bells to take with him. Mother and I had a nice time trying them to night. After that we went out to see the sun set. This has been a delightful  day, and its close was very beautiful. One of my new ideas is constantly dodging into my hear while I am writing perhaps wishing to be noticed on paper, so I'll put it down - "We never saw this day before." I wonder of there ever were two days exactly alike. Another sentence I read to day struck me very forcibly. It is, moreover, an old thought - in a new dress- 'Tis this - "I am a part of all that I have met." It is a solemn thought that we leave impressions on all we meet, as well as receive them.
Completed
Completed

how long it takes now to get letters. I do not see but, with the utmost promptness, there must be as much as four weeks between. Do you find pleasant companions among your company of engineers?  Do you not find the food very different from what you have been accustomed to? This may affect your health.

     I saw Mrs. Raymond Sabbath day. She was obliged for your remembrance and sends to you her kind regards. She said I must tell you she hoped you would not stay in Illinois.
  Parents, brother and sister send much love, but none half so much as your
